data.problemDescription: There is an intermittent issue with the N2K-C2348TQ and N2K-C2348UPQ Fabric Extender (FEX) running NX-OS versions earlier than Version 7.1(1)N1(1). The FEX might not get associated with the parent Nexus 5000/6000 switch on startup, which might result in FEX fabric interfaces that become stuck in a "SDP timeout/SFP Mismatch" state.
data.background: There is a software issue which might cause control packets to not be transmitted between the FEX and the upstream switch.
data.problemSymptoms: The N2K-C2348TQ and N2K-C2348UPQ FEX might not get associated with the parent Nexus 5000/6000 switch on startup, which might result in FEX fabric interfaces that become stuck in a "SDP timeout/SFP Mismatch" state. N6K(config-if-range)# show int eth 1/21-28 brief --------------------------------------------------------------------------------Ethernet InterfaceVLANTypeModeStatusReasonSpeedPort Ch #Eth1/211ethfabricdownSDP timeout/SFP Mismatch10G(D)--Eth1/221ethfabricdownSDP timeout/SFP Mismatch10G(D)--Eth1/231ethfabricdownSDP timeout/SFP Mismatch10G(D)--Eth1/241ethfabricdownSDP timeout/SFP Mismatch10G(D)--Eth1/251ethfabricdownSDP timeout/SFP Mismatch10G(D)--Eth1/261ethfabricdownSDP timeout/SFP Mismatch10G(D)--Eth1/271ethfabricdownSDP timeout/SFP Mismatch10G(D)--Eth1/281ethfabricdownSDP timeout/SFP Mismatch10G(D)--Eth1/291ethfabricdownSDP timeout/SFP Mismatch10G(D)--
data.workaround: As part of the fix in NX-OS Version 7.1(1)N1(1), there have been changes in the Physical Coding Sublayer (PCS) reset mechanism, retries included, which mitigate this problem.If a FEX is stuck in a "SDP timeout/SFP Mismatch" state, there are two options for resolution:- Upgrade the parent Nexus 5000 switch to NX-OS Version 7.1(1)N1(1). Power cycle the FEX multiple times until the FEX downloads the NX-OS image from the parent switch. Once the FEX downloads the fixed image, the issue should not be seen.- If a FEX connected to parent switch that runs fixed code fails to boot up after multiple reloads, a High-Definition Multimedia Interface (HDMI) console dongle is required in order to manually flash the FEX with NX-OS Version 7.1(1)N1(1). For detailed instructions and assistance with the upgrade, please contact Cisco Technical Support at 1-800-553-2447.PSE NOTE: THE WORDING BELOW WILL REQUIRE SOME MODIFICATION PRIOR TO SENDING THIS FIELD NOTICE OUT FOR REVIEW. IN ADDITION, THIS SENTENCE SHOULD BE DELETED PRIOR TO THE REVIEW PHASE.
data.caveat: Matching is only on PID.  Manual verification of software is required.

data.bulletinTitle: FN63999 - Cisco IP Conference Station 8831 Series Locally Significant Certificate (LSC) Issue - Software Upgrade Recommended
data.problemDescription: The Locally Significant Certificates (LSCs) that are installed on the Cisco 8831 Series IP phones are no longer detected when a phone is upgraded from Version 9-3-3-5 to Version 10-3-1-16.
data.background: It might appear that the phone LSC is lost after an upgrade from Version 9-3-3 to Version 10-3-1-16 or later. The LSC is neither removed nor deleted, but it is not detected by the new software.
data.problemSymptoms:
There can be multiple symptoms when this issue is encountered, which include:

The customers might complain that their phone does not work.

The phone User Interface (UI) might display the phone is registering message after the upgrade, but the phone does not register.

The phone UI might display the network unavailable message after the upgrade, but the phone cannot obtain an IP address.

The phone security settings show LSC not installed.

If this problem exists on the customer's network, all 8831's will show the same or similar symptoms after upgrade.

If, after the upgrade, any 8831's on the same network register successfully and others do not, there is most likely another problem happening that is not related to this field notice. It will depend on the security profile of the endpoints. A non-secure 8831 will register without an LSC, where a secure 8831 will not register.
data.workaround:
In order to maintain the original LSC files, the customers must complete these steps in order to upgrade the software:

  1. Upgrade from software Version 9-3-3-5 to Version 9-3-3-TO-10-3-1v2.

  2. Upgrade from software Version 9-3-3-TO-10-3-1v2 to Version 10-3-1-16.

If the customers desire to install the LSC but have not yet installed it, they must upgrade to Version 10.3.1 before the LSC is installed.


Note: The customers who do not use (and have no plans to use) the LSC are not affected by this issue.

data.bulletinTitle: FN64006 - C819HG-xx, C819HG-4G-xx, GRWIC-4G-LTE-x & CGM-3G-XXXX - Possible Corruption of Cellular Data Modem Firmware  - Workaround Provided
data.problemDescription: Select Connected Grid Modules (CGMs) and Integrated Services Routers that run Cisco CGOS or Cisco IOS Release 15.5(3)M1 or earlier might experience corruption of the cellular data modem firmware or modem failure, which results in loss of cellular network connectivity. The potential for these issues increases with frequent power cycling of the modem and enabling GPS in the router.The potentially affected models include C819HG-xx, C819HG-4G-xx, GRWIC-4G-LTE-x, and CGM-3G-XXXX.
data.background: These scenarios might trigger frequent modem power cycling and lead to a modem failure:- Power cycle the router.- Reload the router with the Cisco IOS reload command.- Poor cellular signal strength combined with Cisco IOS Releases earlier than 15.5(3)M1.- An incorrect profile configuration, by itself, does not lead to a modem power cycle. An incorrect profile configuration prevents attaching to the network and customers (Embedded Event Manager (EEM) scripts) might continuously power cycle the modem in an attempt to try to recover it.- EEM or external scripts which power cycle the cellular modem with either the test cellular 0 modem-reset or test cellular 0 modem-power-cycle Cisco IOS commands.C819 and Grid Router WAN interface Cards (GRWICs)For those who use Cisco IOS releases earlier than 15.5(3)M4, it is required to upgrade to 15.5(3)M4 or a later 15.5(3)M release and disable GPS.Note: In Releases15.5(3)M1 or earlier, GPS is enabled by default and cannot be turned off.For those who use Release 15.5(3)M4, it is required to disable GPS.For those who require GPS to be enabled, contact the Cisco Technical Assistance Center (TAC).CGMsFor those who use Cisco CGOS or Cisco IOS releases earlier than 15.5(3)M4, it is required to upgrade to 15.5(3)M4 or a later release. The CGM-3G-XXXX modules are also supported in 15.6(3)M or a later 15.6(3)M release.
data.problemSymptoms: The cellular data modem no longer functions, which results in a loss of cellular network connectivity. A power cycle of the router will not resolve the issue.
data.workaround: C819 and GRWICsComplete these steps in order to mitigate the issue on all the affected PIDs.1. The C819H routers must be upgraded to Release 15.5(3)M4 or a later 15.5(3)M release.2. For the GRWIC-4G-LTE-x modules, the corresponding Connected Grid Router (CGR2xxx) must be upgraded to Release 15.5(3)M4 or a later 15.5(3)M release.3. Remove any EEM or external scripts which power cycle the cellular modem with the test cellular 0 modem-reset or test cellular 0 modem-power-cycle Cisco IOS commands.4. C819HG-V and C819HG-4G-V have a specific requirement to attach with profile one and process data with profile three. Profile two should never be deleted since that prevents the device from attaching to the LTE network. This could result in excessive modem power cycling.5. Disable GPS on the router. See your specific Cisco product documentation for instructions.CGMsComplete these steps in order to mitigate the issue on all the affected PIDs.1. For the CGM-3G-xxxx modules, the corresponding Connected Grid Router (CGR1xxx) must be upgraded to Release 15.5(3)M4 or a later 15.5(3)M or a 15.6(3)M release. If the CGR1xxx runs CGOS, it must be migrated to Cisco IOS 15.5(3)M4 or a later 15.5(3)M or a 15.6(3)M release.2. Remove any EEM or external scripts which power cycle the cellular modem with the test cellular 0 modem-reset or test cellular 0 modem-power-cycle Cisco IOS commands.3. CGM-3G-EVDO-V has a specific requirement to attach with profile one and process data with profile three. Profile two should never be deleted since that prevents the device from attaching to the LTE network. This could result in excessive modem power cycling.
data.caveat: Matching is based on PID only.  Manual verification of software version will be required.

data.bulletinTitle: FN64007 - PI-UCS-APL-K9 - Generation 2 Prime Infrastructure Appliance FlexFlash Faults - Workaround Provided
data.problemDescription:
Some of the new Generation 2 Prime Infrastructure Appliance units might report a moderate fault and/or display an illuminated amber LED when powered up for the first time.

This issue involves two onboard flash cards, called Cisco FlexFlash, that are used in order to hold small images (less than 32 GB) for bootups in certain configurations. The FlexFlash is typically composed of two 32-GB flash cards that are mirrored to each other. If the two become un-mirrored, a moderate fault is generated on the unit.
data.background: There is no additional background information for this issue.
data.problemSymptoms:
When this problem occurs, a Moderate Fault message is generated and/or an illuminated amber LED is displayed when the unit is powered up for the first time.

The Moderate Fault error message is displayed via the Cisco Integrated Management Controller (CIMC) appliance software.
data.workaround:
This problem is currently under investigation.

Refer to the Troubleshoot Generation 2 Prime Infrastructure Appliance FlexFlash Faults Cisco support document in order to view a workaround for this issue.
data.caveat: Matching is based on PID only.  Manually validate against all the criteria in the Field Notice.

data.bulletinTitle: FN64010 - RFGW-1 Might Fail to Boot Up After a Software Upgrade or Power Cycle - Replace on Failure
data.problemDescription: Some RFGW-1 units might fail to boot up after a software upgrade or other user actions where the board requires a power cycle operation.
data.background: Cisco has been working with some customers on an issue related to memory components manufactured by a single supplier between 2005 and 2010. These memory components are widely used across the industry and are included in a number of Cisco products.Although the majority of Cisco products using these components are experiencing field failure rates below expected levels, some components may fail earlier than anticipated. A handful of our customers have recently experienced a higher number of failures, leading us to change our approach to managing this issue.While other vendors have chosen to address this issue in different ways, Cisco believes its approach is the best course of action for its customers. Despite the cost, we are demonstrating that we always make customer satisfaction a top priority. Customers can learn more about this topic at Memory Component Issue web page.PLEASE NOTE - The products listed in this Field Notice have lower than expected failure rates. This assessment is based on actual usage of affected memory components, observed field failure rates and product replacements since 2012.A degraded component will not affect the ongoing operation of a device, but will be exposed by a subsequent power cycle event. This event will result in a hard failure of the device, which cannot be recovered by a reboot or additional power cycle. For these reasons, additional caution is recommended for operational activities requiring the simultaneous power cycling of multiple devices. This issue has been observed most commonly on devices that have been in service for 24 months or more.
data.problemSymptoms: If the suspected hardware (listed in the Products Affected section) has been in operation for approximately 24 months, the product hardware might fail to boot up due to memory failure during a power cycle event caused by one or more of these actions:- Upgrade the software- Reload the entire product- Reload after installation- Online Insertion Removal/Replacement (OIR)Note: The issue does not affect the chassis while in operation. A chassis failure might occur after one of the previous actions is taken.There has been only one observed symptom to date; failure to boot.
data.workaround: Normal SmartNet and warranty entitlement rules remain in place and are applied by the Cisco Technical Assistance Center (TAC) if you experience a failure in one of the products listed in the Field Notice. If you need assistance in order to determine which hardware part(s) might need replacement or if the product is out of warranty or out of contract, Cisco encourages you to raise your concern directly with your Cisco account team.Fix on Failure Replacement Guidelines: Request RMA product through normal service support channels.PID ActionReplace the chassis with Product ID (PID) CHAS-RFGW-1=.
data.caveat: Matching is based on PID only.  See field notice for details about the conditions that cause the device to fail.

data.bulletinTitle: FN64014 - ASR1006-X, ASR1009-X and ASR1000-RP2 - RP2 CPLD Incompatible with New Chassis - Software Upgrade Recommended
data.problemDescription: An ASR1000-RP2 with an old Complex Programmable Logic Device (CPLD) (version earlier than 14111801) is not compatible with the new ASR1006-X and ASR1009-X chassis.When you boot an ASR1000-RP2 that has an old CPLD (version earlier than 14111801) with an XE3.16.0 RP2 image on the ASR1006-X or ASR1009-X chassis, the messages displayed on the screen are confusing and misleading.
data.background: The ASR1000-RP2 requires CPLD version 14111801 (or later) in order to recognize the ASR1006-X or ASR1009-X chassis. If the RP2 is installed with an old CPLD on the ASR1006-X or ASR1009-X chassis, all of the cards will be held in reset except for the Active RP2. The log indicates the active RP2 has an incompatible CPLD and the solution is to upgrade RP2's CPLD. Besides the RP2 message, false Power Supply and Fan Module alarms are also raised and the messages indicate that the CPLDs on other cards are also incompatible. These messages are incorrect. The line card and Embedded Services Processor (ESP) card CPLDs are fine and are not required to be upgraded.
data.problemSymptoms: This sample output is a representation of the incorrect messages that will occur if the active RP2 CPLD is not upgraded. The only Field Replaceable Unit (FRU) that actually requires an upgrade when moved to the ASR1006-X or ASR1009-X is the RP2. All logs and the show platform command state messages are irrelevant except for RP2.The lines in BOLD are the correct messages that indicate the need to upgrade the RP2 CPLD. All other lines are misleading and can be ignored.Router# show platformChassis type: ASR1009-X Slot      Type                State                 Insert time (ago)--------- ------------------- --------------------- -----------------0         ASR1000-SIP40       act_rp_cpld_incompatib00:07:53R0        ASR1000-RP2         act_rp_cpld_incompatib00:07:53R1        ASR1000-RP2         act_rp_cpld_incompatib00:03:58F0        ASR1000-ESP40       act_rp_cpld_incompatib00:07:53P0        Unknown             ps, fail              neverP1        Unknown             ps, fail              neverP2        Unknown             ps, fail              neverP6        Unknown             ps, fail              neverP7        Unknown             ps, fail              neverP8        Unknown             ps, fail              never Slot      CPLD Version        Firmware Version--------- ------------------- ---------------------------------------0         N/A                 N/A1         N/A                 N/AR0        08103002            15.4(2r)SR1        10021901            15.2(1r)SF0        N/A                 N/AF1        N/A                 N/A *Jul  2 19:35:09.110: : %CMRP-3-RP_CPLD_INCOMPATIBLE: R0/0: cmand:  All other cards in the system have been held in reset as the  Active RP ASR1000-RP2 in slot R0 has CPLD firmware version that is incompatible with ASR1009-X. *Jul  2 19:35:09.210: %CMRP-3-FRU_CPLD_INCOMPATIBLE: R0/0: cmand:  ASR1000-ESP40 in slot F1 has been held in reset as its CPLD firmware  version is incompatible with ASR1009-X*Jul  2 19:37:01.896: %CMRP-3-FRU_CPLD_INCOMPATIBLE: R0/0: cmand:  ASR1000-SIP40 in slot 0 has been held in reset as its CPLD firmware  version is incompatible with ASR1009-X*Jul  2 19:37:12.731: %IOSXE_OIR-6-ONLINECARD: Card (rp) online in slot R1*Jul  2 19:37:12.738: %CMRP-3-FRU_CPLD_INCOMPATIBLE: R0/0: cmand:  ASR1000-RP2 in slot R1 has been held in reset as its CPLD firmware  version is incompatible with ASR1009-X*Jul  2 19:37:12.951: %IOSXE_OIR-6-OFFLINECARD: Card (rp) offline in slot R1 *Jul  2 19:35:36.440: %CMRP_PFU-4-PWR_MGMT_WARN: R0/0: cmand:  WARNING: Insufficient number of power supplies (0) is installed for power redundancy mode none. The system needs 1057 watts additional power.
data.workaround: In order to upgrade the RP2 CPLD, complete these steps:1. Ignore false alarm messages due to this condition.2. Download the asr1000-hw-programmables package, which has the new RP2 CPLD, in order to upgrade the active RP CPLD.3. Store the package on the active RP2 hard disk.4. Follow the recommended procedure in order to upgrade the RP2 CPLD in the ASR1006-X or ASR1009-X:a. At the Cisco IOS prompt, enter the upgrade hw-programmble cpld file harddisk:asr1000-hw-programmables.03.16.0a.S.155-3S0a-ext.pkg  command.You will see this message:Upgrade CPLD on Route-Processor 0 from current version 10021901 to 14111801 [Press Enter to confirm]This command could take up to 10 minutes, please wait and do not power-cycle the chassis or the card. Otherwise, hardware may be unrecoverable. It is recommended that all cards are running the same version IOS-XE software prior to the upgrade. At the end of upgrade you will be asked to reload the chassis. [Press Enter to confirm]Upgrade cpld hw-programmable on Route-Processor 0The cpld has been successfully upgraded on Route-Processor/0....b. After you upgrade the active RP2, POWER CYCLE the chassis in order to complete the process. This step is mandatory since the reload of the chassis will not be sufficient to finish the upgrade.c. Change the active_rp2_slot with the upgrade command in order to perform the same CPLD upgrade on another RP2.   Note: It is possible to also upgrade the RP2 CPLD on the ASR1004, ASR1006, and ASR1013 chassis.PSE NOTE: THE WORDING BELOW WILL REQUIRE SOME MODIFICATION PRIOR TO SENDING THIS FIELD NOTICE OUT FOR REVIEW. IN ADDITION, THIS SENTENCE SHOULD BE DELETED PRIOR TO THE REVIEW PHASE.
data.caveat: Matching is based on PID.  Manual verification of CPLD version will be required.

data.bulletinTitle: FN64024 - ASR-920-PWR-A Might Fail to Start on Power Up - Replace on Failure
data.problemDescription: The Power Supply Unit ASR-920-PWR-A might fail to start up when it is powered on, which causes the ASR 920 routers to not power up.  Replacement of the Power Supply Unit ASR-920-PWR-A is required in order to avoid this issue.
data.background: Cisco has identified a component design issue in the Power Supply Unit ASR-920-PWR-A used in these ASR 920 routers: ASR-920-24SZ-M, ASR-920-24SZ-IM, and ASR-920-24TZ-M.  The root cause has been identified as an auxiliary transformer that causes high overshoot and triggers the Logical Link Controller (LLC) Overvoltage Protection (OVP) (20V) when the Power Supply Unit starts up. This might cause the ASR 920 routers to not power up in the power cycle.
data.problemSymptoms: The ASR920 router might not power up in the power cycle or a single Power Supply Unit (the ASR-920-PWR-A) in the redundant setup might fail to power up.
data.workaround: Cisco recommends proactive replacement for this issue. Customers whose units show "Affected" in the "How to Identify Affected Hardware" section are requested to complete the Upgrade Request form in the "Upgrade Program" section of this field notice.

data.bulletinTitle: FN64025 - Adhere to Hardware Installation Guide - WS-C3560CX and WS-C2960CX - Workaround Provided
data.problemDescription: The screws might not be installed to the correct depth as described in the Hardware Installation Guide for WS-C3560CX and WS-C2960CX switches that are mounted to a desk, shelf, or wall with mounting screws (without a mounting tray). This installation error, coupled with appreciable force in order to mount the switch, might cause the insulator to be punctured which exposes a voltage circuit. When the screw and voltage circuit touch, a short circuit between the voltage part and the chassis ground occurs. This might result in an electrical shock for a very short time period before the unit fails.
data.background:
Potentially impacted customers: Only customers who will mount or remount the switch to a desk, shelf, or wall with mounting screws (without a mounting tray).

Customers not impacted: Customers who have mounted the switch with a mounting tray, mounted the switch in a rack, or already mounted the switch to a desk, shelf, or wall with mounting screws (and the switch currently works).
data.problemSymptoms:
If the switch is mounted to a desk, shelf, or wall with mounting screws (without a mounting tray), this could occur when:

- The installer did not follow the mounting instructions, as described in the Hardware Installation Guide, which state the required screw depth per the provided screw template.

- The installer might have energized the product prior to mounting.

- Dependent upon on the screw depth, when the installer uses an appreciable force (30 lbs. or more) in order to mount the switch the insulator might be punctured which exposes a voltage circuit. When the screw and voltage circuit touch, a short circuit between the voltage part and the chassis ground occurs. This might result in an electrical shock for a very short time period before the unit fails.

If mounting instructions are not followed, a low risk of a potential electric shock exists.
data.workaround:
The wall-mounting instructions can be found in the Hardware Installation Guide. The desk- or shelf-mounting instructions are very similar and can also be found in the Hardware Installation Guide.





Cisco strongly recommends to use the mounting tray for safety reasons. For customers who want to install the switch with the mounting tray (CMPCT-MGNT-TRAY), contact the Technical Assistance Center (TAC) for assistance.
data.caveat: Matching is only based on PID.  Manual verification of mount is required.

data.bulletinTitle: FN64027 - Bezel Print Error - Workaround Provided
data.problemDescription: Cisco noticed an artwork discrepancy on the faceplate's labels of WS-X4712-SFP-E and WS-X4724-SFP-E.?Both of the labels display "48-PORT" instead of "12-PORT" or "24-PORT".No functional or technical defect is found in the product with this bezel print error.
data.background: Cisco noticed that the artwork for both WS-X4712-SFP-E (P/N 47-25938-01) and WS-X4724-SFP-E (P/N 47-25939-01) refer to 56-19829-01 which is for 48-PORT.
data.problemSymptoms: There is an artwork discrepancy on the faceplate's labels, PN 47-25938-01 and PN 47-25939-01.
data.workaround: This is a minor cosmetic print error and Cisco has fixed it with the release of correct artwork for both WS-X4712-SFP-E and WS-X4724-SFP-E.As of approximately 12-July-2015, new products that are manufactured are guaranteed to be free of this print error.No product functional issue is associated with this field notice and no further action is needed.

data.bulletinTitle: FN64034 - DCM Might Fail to Boot After Software Upgrade or Power Cycle - Replace on Failure
data.problemDescription: Cisco Digital Content Manager (DCM) Series D9900 chassis, D9901 chassis or cards might fail to boot up after a software upgrade or other actions where the unit or card requires a power cycle operation. NOTE: Refer to the "Other Considerations" section of this Field Notice for a list of impacted legacy Scientific Atlanta Part Numbers.
data.background: Cisco has been working with some customers on an issue related to memory components manufactured by a single supplier between 2005 and 2010. These memory components are widely used across the industry and are included in a number of Cisco products. Although the majority of Cisco products using these components are experiencing field failure rates below expected levels, some components may fail earlier than anticipated. A handful of our customers have recently experienced a higher number of failures, leading us to change our approach to managing this issue. While other vendors have chosen to address this issue in different ways, Cisco believes its approach is the best course of action for its customers. Despite the cost, we are demonstrating that we always make customer satisfaction a top priority. Customers can learn more about this topic at Memory Component Issue web page. PLEASE NOTE - The products listed in this Field Notice have lower than expected failure rates. This assessment is based on actual usage of affected memory components, observed field failure rates and product replacements since 2012. A degraded component will not affect the ongoing operation of a device, but will be exposed by a subsequent power cycle event. This event will result in a hard failure of the device, which cannot be recovered by a reboot or additional power cycle. For these reasons, additional caution is recommended for operational activities requiring the simultaneous power cycling of multiple devices. This issue has been observed most commonly on devices that have been in service for 24 months or more.
data.problemSymptoms: If the suspected hardware (listed in the Products Affected section) has been in operation for approximately 24 months, the product hardware might fail to boot up due to memory failure during a power cycle event or when you perform an in-operation software upgrade. Problem Symptom on the DCM Chassis No LEDS illuminate on the front panel, but the fans are in operation. Note: If the power supply unit (PSU) fails, both the front LEDS are extinguished and the fans do not operate. Problem Symptom on a DCM I/O Card No specific symptom for this particular issue.
data.workaround:
Normal SmartNet and warranty entitlement rules remain in place and are applied by the Cisco Technical Assistance Center (TAC) if you experience a failure in one of the products listed in the Field Notice. If you need assistance in order to determine which hardware part(s) might need replacement or if the product is out of warranty or out of contract, Cisco encourages you to raise your concern directly with your Cisco account team. 

Fix on Failure Replacement Guidelines: Request RMA product through normal service support channels.
data.caveat: Matching is only based on PID.  Refer to Field Notice for other conditions that should be checked.

data.bulletinTitle: FN64063 - LED Missing from C896VAG-LTE-K9, C897VAG-LTE-K9, C898EAG-LTE-K9, and C897VAMG-LTE-GA-K9 - Replace on Failure
data.problemDescription: On affected SKUs, listed in the Products Affected section, two LEDs and two resistors were not added to the Bill of Materials and therefore those LEDs and resistors are not populated on production units. As a result, GE8 and SFP8 WAN ports do not provide visual indication of the link status or data activity. The user is unable to look at the router in order to determine whether the port is active or not active.
data.background: Two LED resistors were left off of the Bill of Materials for the these Cisco Product IDs (PIDs):- C896VAG-LTE-GA-K9- C897VAG-LTE-GA-K9- C897VAMG-LTE-GA-K9- C898EAG-LTE-GA-K9
data.problemSymptoms: GE8 and SFP8 have no LED indication of link status or data activity on production units. When either port is active the user will have no visible indication of port status.
data.workaround: The workaround is to view port status from the CLI or replace these units via standard RMA processNotes:- Cisco will provide parts only. No field assistance will be available for installation.- If your device comes with the POE option, specify that when opening the RMA- Devices will come with the latest firmware 5.5.58.0 mainline Cisco IOS? 15.5(3)M.- Specify the type of power cord based on your geographic location when opening the RMA

data.bulletinTitle: FN64065 - Catalyst 3850 Switches Might Falsely Log Power Device Connect/Disconnect Messages - Workaround Provided
data.problemDescription: Some Catalyst 3850 switches might log power device detected/removed log messages when there is no device connected. The logs might appear continuously.Cisco has determined there is no functionality impact due to this issue.Devices will continue to operate correctly when connected to the switch ports.
data.background: Products which can be affected by this issue are listed in the "Products Affected" field AND serial number range given below:- FCW1927xxxx through FCW1939xxxx- FOC1927xxxx through FOC1939xxxxSee the "How To Identify Hardware Levels" section in order to determine if a particular switch is affected. This issue is seen across all supported software releases.
data.problemSymptoms: These messages might be seen continuously on the screen.Multiple downlink ports on PoE/uPoE switches in the network might log these messages on the console orbuffer based on the customer configuration.*Sep 10 20:35:46.761: %ILPOWER-7-DETECT: Interface Gi1/0/4: Power Device detected: Cisco PD*Sep 10 20:35:47.920: %ILPOWER-5-POWER_GRANTED: Interface Gi1/0/4: Power granted*Sep 10 20:35:48.085: %ILPOWER-5-IEEE_DISCONNECT: Interface Gi1/0/4: PD removed
data.workaround: Option 1Disable logging for level 5 and higher.Switch(config)#logging console 4Switch(config)#logging buffered 4switch(config)#logging monitor 4switch(config)#logging host 4 Option 2 Disable inline-power log events.Switch(config)# interface range Gigabit/0/1 - , Gigabit/0/1 - , ... Switch(config)#no logging event power-inline-status  Option 1 OR 2 can be used pending a permanent fix in a future software release.Cisco IOS 3.6.4E IOS XE and 3.7.3E IOS XE planned for release in January 2016
data.caveat: Matching is done on PID and Serial Number only.  Manual verification of work-around or software upgrade, when available, is necessary.

data.bulletinTitle: FN64068 - N7000: M2 and F2 Line Card Reset Due to EOBC Heartbeat Failure - Software Upgrade Recommended
data.problemDescription: The M2, F2, and NAM line cards, as listed in the Products Affected section, might be reset by the Supervisor due to the Ethernet Out of Band Channel (EOBC) heartbeat that is missed by the line card. This EOBC heartbeat communication, which consists of diagnostic and system management signals, is essential for the line card to function properly.
data.background: In scenarios where customers run NX OS versions earlier than Version 6.2 (14), there are communication issues between the Supervisor and the M2, F2, and NAM line cards where heartbeats go missing between the full duplex Gigabit link. This EOBC heartbeat communication, which consists of diagnostic and system management signals, is essential for the M2, F2, and NAM line cards to function properly.
data.problemSymptoms: This system error code shows the "EOBC heartbeat failure" message. exception information --- exception instance 4 ----Module Slot Number: 3Device Id         : 10Device Name       : eobcDevice Errorcode  : 0xc0a0114fDevice ID         : 10 (0x0a)Device Instance   : 01 (0x01)Dev Type (HW/SW)  : 01 (0x01)ErrNum (devInfo)  : 79 (0x4f)System Errorcode  : 0x4042004e EOBC heartbeat failureError Type        : WarningPhyPortLayer      : EthernetPort(s) Affected  :DSAP              : 0 (0x0)UUID              : 0 (0x0)Time              : Sun Dec 28 01:34:28 2014                    (Ticks: 549F33F4 jiffies)ORCheck the module's internal activity logs. For example, enter the show module internal activity module [slot number] command.Near the time when the linecard is reloaded, you might see events in the model's internal activity logs such as follows:Warning on ports: 1-0 due to EOBC heartbeat failure in device 10
data.workaround: Customers should upgrade the NX OS software to Version 6.2 (14) or later. No Return Material Authorization (RMA) is required.Dual Supervisor Modules - This  Upgrade Procedure Summary describes how to upgrade a device that has dual supervisor modules to the latest Cisco NX-OS software.Single Supervisor Module - This Upgrade Procedure Summary  describes how to upgrade a device that has a single supervisor module to the latest Cisco NX-OS software.
data.caveat: Matching is only on PID.  Manual verification of software version will be required.

data.bulletinTitle: FN64069 - ASA 5506, 5506W, 5506H, 5508, and 5516 Security Appliances Shipped Without ASDM Management Software - Software Upgrade Recommended
data.problemDescription: Some ASA5506, ASA5506W, ASA5506H, ASA5508, and ASA5516 security appliances were shipped without the Adaptive Security Device Manager (ASDM) on-box management software.
data.background: Some ASA5506, ASA5506W, ASA5506H, ASA5508, and ASA5516 security appliances that shipped from February 2015 through October 2015 might not contain the ASDM on-box management software.This requires the user to download the ASDM management software from the Cisco Software Download Center and install the software on affected units.
data.problemSymptoms: Use one of these methods in order to determine if the ASDM management software is not installed on the appliance:From the Web User Interface, the directory command shows this output:'404 Not Found The requested URL /admin/public/index.html was not found on this server.'From the console port CLI, the directory command will not display filename asdm-7xx.bin.
data.workaround: Install ASDM 7.5.1 management software from the Cisco Software Download Center. A support contract is not required in order to download filename 'asdm-751.bin.'
data.caveat: Matching based on PID only and for your information.  See field notice for details.

data.bulletinTitle: FN64071 - CP-8831 DCU (Keypad) Problems - Software Upgrade Recommended
data.problemDescription:
CP-8831 with a V02 keyboard boots up to a blank LCD at installation or shows the Cisco logo. The 8831 appears as if the keyboard unit (display control unit - DCU) is bad, however this is not the case. This occurs when the 8831 has been downgraded to firmware version 9.3.3. In order to fix the issue the phone must be upgraded back to 10.3.1SR2, which requires a stepped upgrade. Details are in the Workaround/Solution section.

All units with serial numbers between FOC1926xxxx and  FOC1952xxxx are affected.
data.background:
In manufacturing there was a component change to the DCU that requires new firmware in order to operate. The original firmware 9.3.3 does not contain the driver necessary to operate the DCU. That driver is only available in firmware versions 10.3.1-SR1 and later.

The 10.3.1-SR1 firmware does not have the blocker that prevents the 8831 from downgrading to an earlier firmware version.

Customers who have standardized on the 9.3.3 firmware, for example, will see their new 8831 downgrade to 9.3.3 automatically which disables the operation of the DCU.

Even if the customer completes a Return Material Authorization (RMA) for the 8831 and installs a new replacement 8831, the same problem occurs because of the way the firmware is managed.
data.problemSymptoms: CP-8831 boots up to either a blank LCD or an LCD that shows the Cisco logo at installation. The unit shows registered in CUCM and might receive calls, but no calls can be placed.
data.workaround: All units with serial numbers between FOC1926xxxx and FOC1952xxxx are affected. For CP-8831 devices with a V01 designation, no action is required. These devices do not have the new DCU hardware and therefore have no driver dependency within the firmware. For CP-8831 devices with a V02 designation, in order to prevent this issue from occurring, see the Solution section. If this issue has already occurred and is need of recovery, see the Workaround section. It is possible, at the time of this release, that 10.3.1(SR2) will not yet be published. In that case use 10.3.1(SR1). Solution In order to prevent the 8831 V02 from downgrading firmware prior to connection to the network when the CUCM default load is 9.3.3, complete these steps: 1. Download 10.3.1-SR2 from Cisco.com. 2. Load the 10.3.1-SR2 firmware onto the TFTP server. 3. Restart the TFTP service on the CUCM. 4. Point the new 8831 to the 10.3.1-SR2 load from the administration page for each new device. 5. Connect a new 8831 to the network and it will upgrade to 10.3.1-SR2. Workaround In order to recover CP-8831 V02 units that have already downgraded to 9.3.3, complete these steps: 1. Download cmterm-8831-sip.9-3-3-TO-10-3-1-v2.zip from Cisco.com. 2. Load the cmterm-8831-sip.9-3-3-TO-10-3-1-v2.zip firmware onto the TFTP server from the TFTP File Management Page. 3. Restart the TFTP service on the CUCM. 4. Point the new 8831 to the cmterm-8831-sip.9-3-3-TO-10-3-1-v2.zip load from the administration page for each new device. 5. Connect a new 8831 to the network. 6. After the 8831 has upgraded to 9-3-3-TO-10-3-1-v2, point the 8831 to the 10.3.1-SR2 load from the administration page for each new device. 7. Initiate reset to load 10.3.1-SR2. Firmware releases 10.3.1 SR2 and later contain the downgrade blocker.

data.bulletinTitle: FN64079 - ASA 5506W-X Security Appliances - Some Units Shipped With Non-Production Software - Hardware Upgrade Required
data.problemDescription: Some ASA 5506W-X security appliances were shipped with non-production software. As a result, some ASA 5506W-X units might not meet local wireless regulatory standards.
data.background: All ASA 5506W-X security appliances that shipped from April 18, 2015 through November 11, 2015 contain non-production software. As a result, these ASA 5506W-X units might not meet local wireless regulatory standards. Affected units are not field upgradable and hardware replacement is required.
data.problemSymptoms: Affected ASA 5506W-X security appliances might not meet local wireless regulatory standards.
data.workaround: Cisco recommends replacement of the affected ASA 5506W-X security appliances.

data.bulletinTitle: FN64080 - IPS Sensors - Software Upgrade Required in Order to Enable SHA-2 Support For IPS Signature Updates - Software Upgrade Recommended
FN64093 - UCSC Series Default Password for Units Shipped November 17, 2015 through January 6, 2016 is Incorrect - Configuration Change Recommended
data.problemDescription: A number of C-Series servers have shipped to customers with a non-standard default password which prevents access to the Cisco Integrated Management Controller (CIMC) unless the configured password is provided.
data.background: Systems manufactured between November 17, 2015 and January 6, 2016 were produced with a different default password.
data.problemSymptoms: Customers might not be able to log in to their C-Series servers with the published default admin password "password" since this has been changed to "Cisco1234" for these systems. Customers should access the CIMC interface with this combination "admin":"Cisco1234" and set the password back to the default or a customer desired password.
data.workaround:
Workaround #1(Recommended) Log in to the system with this alternate password "Cisco1234" and change it to a known password. Workaround #2 Connect crash cart to the system. Power the system on and use the F8 menu in order to reset the CIMC to factory defaults or change the admin password:


Workaround #3 Note: This workaround assumes that the CIMC is online and the IP address is known. This solution is for customers who used DHCP to IP the CIMC(s). Use XML API in order to log in to one or more system and change the password. A sample script is provided: 1. Download IMC PowerTool module from IMC PowerTool. 2. Save and run this file as a .ps1 file: Import-Module CiscoImcPs $multiimc = Set-ImcPowerToolConfiguration -SupportMultipleDefaultImc $true # The tool prompts the user to enter IP addresses when run. $imclist = Read-Host "Enter Cisco IMC IP or list of IMC IPs separated by commas" [array]$imclist = ($imclist.split(",")).trim() $user = 'admin' # The non-standard password is on the next line (update as needed). $pass = ConvertTo-SecureString -String "Cisco1234" -AsPlainText -Force $cred = New-Object -TypeName System.Management.Automation.PSCredential -ArgumentList $user, $pass $out = Connect-Imc -Credential $cred $imclist # The password on the next line is the new password for this user. $newpass = "password" Get-ImcLocalUser -Id 1 | Set-ImcLocalUser -Pwd $newpass -Force | Out-GridView $out = Disconnect-Imc
data.caveat: Matching is only based on PID and for your information to be aware of the potentially different default password.

data.bulletinTitle: FN64094 - Nexus 5596/UCS FI 6296 - System Fails to Boot After a Power Cycle - Workaround Provided
data.problemDescription: Some Nexus 5596 and Unified Computing System Fabric Interconnect (UCS FI) 6296 systems fail to boot after a software upgrade, reload, or power cycle. This problem is rare in occurrence but has been seen in the field.The failure signature is no console output and the status LED remains solid green.The issue is only seen on N5K-C5596UP, N5K-C5596T, and UCS-FI-6296UP. This DOES NOT affect the Nexus 50x0, Nexus 5548, Nexus 5600 Series, UCS FI 6100 Series, or UCS FI 6248.
data.background: There are two power controller devices in the system and each controller device controls four ASIC devices 0.9V power rails on board. It was found that the firmware on the two controllers have different soft-start compensation parameters.In order to correct the issue a script needs to be run on the system to update the controller settings. This can be done in the field, but requires assistance from the Technical Assistance Center (TAC).
data.problemSymptoms: After a power cycle there is no console output and the status LED remains solid green.
data.workaround: Refer to the "How to Identify Hardware Levels" section for instructions on how to view the version of an in-service product.If the hardware shows the Updated Hardware Version or later, no action is required.If the hardware shows the Impacted Hardware Version or earlier, please call TAC or your account team for further assistance. The controller configuration settings can be corrected in the field with TAC assistance.
data.caveat: Matching is based on PID only.  The HW Rev is for the Supervisor, which is not a FRU.  As a result, that must be manually validated using the process identified in the field notice.

data.bulletinTitle: FN64096 - NIM-2GE-CU-SFP(=) Module Can Overheat and Cause Packet Loss or Module Failure - Replace on Failure
data.problemDescription: The heatsink and fan in some NIM-2GE-CU-SFP modules might not properly cool high powered chips introduced in manufacturing. This might lead the chips to overheat, packet loss, reloads, and could cause the device to no longer function. The issue was discovered at one customer site in the field. There are no safety concerns associated with the overheating. Cisco has created a hardware replacement program in order to replace any potentially affected units in the field due to the reliability issues.
data.background: After investigation into the failure of one unit, it was discovered that the thermal solutions (heatsink and fan) did not properly cool some chips with higher power output.
data.problemSymptoms: The user might see console log messages which indicate reload issues with the module. An example of the messages are shown in this section. The module might also no longer show up in the show inventory command.
data.workaround: Fix on failure via normal RMA process

data.bulletinTitle: FN64102 - IE5000 - Potential Damage to the Source Wiring Can Cause a Short to the Metal Enclosure
data.problemDescription: Potential damage to the source wiring can cause a short to the metal enclosure/barrier. This could lead to a potential electrical and/or fire safety hazard for the end user. This issue has not been observed at a customer site. It was observed in a single device that had not yet been shipped. As a result, Cisco has created a hardware upgrade program to replace any impacted units.
data.background: A single switch was discovered to possess a short in the power harness cable during a manufacturing test. The power harness cable appeared to be damaged by a metallic baffle.
data.problemSymptoms: The switch fails to power up.
data.workaround: Replace the affected hardware through the "Upgrade Program" section listed in this Field Notice.  Refer to "How to Identify Hardware Levels" for instructions on how to validate impacted units.

data.bulletinTitle: FN64106 - Nexus N56-M24UP2Q Modules Incompatibility Issue - Replace on Failure
data.problemDescription: Some Nexus N56-M24UP2Q modules are incompatible with certain Nexus N5K-C56128P chassis and fail to change to online status when plugged into the chassis.
data.background: The N56-M24UPQ module and N5K-C56128P chassis underwent a hardware revision in Dec 2015. Although low in occurrence, certain N56-M24UPQ modules released after this revision are incompatible with N5K-C56128P chassis released prior to the revision.N56-M24UP2Q modules with top assembly number (TAN) 68-5671-01 are not compatible with N5K-C56128P chassis that have TAN 68-5193-02 or 68-5193-03.N56-M24UP2Q modules with TAN other than 68-5671-01 are compatible with any hardware version of the N5K-C56128P chassis.Cisco has determined the root cause of the problem and identified a fix which was implemented through a minor hardware revision on the modules. This fix enables the N56-M24UP2Q modules to be compatible with any version of the N5K-C56128P chassis.
data.problemSymptoms: This error can be seen upon module insertion:Module X insertion failed. Module may not be seated properly or of wrong type. Remove module, ensure correct type and re-insert after five or more seconds.
data.workaround: If the hardware shows an incompatible configuration as described in the "Background" section, request a replacement N56-M24UPQ module via the form in the "Upgrade Program" section.If the hardware shows a compatible configuration, the error is not due to Cisco bug ID CSCut89127 and the Upgrade Program should not be leveraged.Refer to the "How to Identify Hardware Levels" section for instructions on how to view the TAN versions of the module and chassis.
data.caveat: Automated matching is on PID and TAN.  The issue in this Field Notice is a compatibility issue with parent chassis, which is not being automatically checked.

data.bulletinTitle: FN64110 - Nexus 5600 or Nexus 6001 Series Switch Might Hang or Reset - BIOS/Firmware Upgrade Recommended
data.problemDescription: A Nexus 6001 Series or Nexus 5600 Series switch might hang or reboot with no response via the console, mgmt0, or inband interfaces.
data.background: A Nexus 6001 or 5600 Series switch might experience hangs or reboots during a storm of non-maskable hardware interrupts (NMIs) to the main CPU. An interrupt is a message sent between hardware components in the system, and "non-maskable" refers to the fact that the receiving side normally cannot ignore the message. In the context of this issue, the NMI messages originate from the chassis PCIe bus are caused by a software defect or hardware component failure.
data.problemSymptoms: There are three methods to identify this issue:1. If the switch runs NX-OS 7.0(3)N1(1) and later, it can raise a syslog event when excessive interrupts are generated on the PCIe bus.Example:%USER-0-SYSTEM_MSG: 2032: PCIe critical FAILURE DETECTED, contact Cisco TAC - pfm2. During the NMI storm to the CPU, erroneous messages are often written to the "uC reset code" field within the reload records which indicates a "microcontroller brownout" (platform reload) occurred when one did not occur.Example:SWITCH# show logging onboard internal reset-reasonMon Jan 1 00:00:00 2015: Card Uptime Record----------------------------------------------Uptime: 0, 0 days 0 hour(s) 0 minute(s) 0 second(s)Reset Reason: Unknown (0)Reset Reason SW: Unknown (0)Reset Reason (HW): uC reset code: 0x4800Host Requested Reset: reloadMicrocontroller Detected Platform Reset <=====3. The most reliable method to identify the issue is to run the following command several times back to back waiting about a minute in-between. This command tells you if NMI events occur in the background:show system internal file /proc/interrupts  incl NMIExample:SWITCH# show system internal file /proc/interrupts  incl NMINMI: 57000 0 0 0 0 0 0 0 Non-maskable interruptsSWITCH# show system internal file /proc/interrupts  incl NMINMI: 58000 0 0 0 0 0 0 0 Non-maskable interruptsSWITCH# show system internal file /proc/interrupts  incl NMINMI: 59000 0 0 0 0 0 0 0 Non-maskable interruptsPCIe errors can also result from a hardware component failure. If running one of the fixed NX-OS versions, the system will generate the following syslog messages if the PCIE errors are due to hardware component failure: In NX-OS 7.0(8)N1(1)2016 Aug 11 06:56:20 N6001 %NOHMS-2-NOHMS_ENV_SERR: Bus:Dev.Func 0a:00.00 Vendor 0x1137 Device0xbe is giving out high correctable Error .. 2016 Aug 11 06:56:20 N6001 %NOHMS-2-NOHMS_ENV_SERR: Bus:Dev.Func 13:00.00 Vendor 0x1137 Device0xbe is giving out high correctable Error .. 2016 Aug 11 06:56:20 N6001 %NOHMS-2-NOHMS_ENV_SERR: Bus:Dev.Func 0f:00.00 Vendor 0x1137 Device0xbe is giving out high correctable Error .. In NX-OS 7.1(4)N1(1) or 7.3(1)N1(1)2016 Aug 16 13:44:06.686 N56128 %NOHMS-2-NOHMS_ENV_PCI: Bus:Dev.Func 00:01.01 Vendor 0x8086 DeviceID 0x155 PCIe critical FAILURE DETECTED (1-C/1), Contact Cisco TAC2016 Aug 16 13:44:06.686 N56128 %NOHMS-2-NOHMS_ENV_PCI: Bus:Dev.Func 18:00.00 Vendor 0x10b5 DeviceID 0x8608 PCIe critical FAILURE DETECTED (1-C/1), Contact Cisco TAC The show command  show nohms pcie counter  can be used to view these details in the fixed NX-OS versions only.
data.workaround: The software issue has been fixed in the form of a BIOS update in later NX-OS releases. Upgrade the BIOS of the impacted switch to any Fixed-In NX-OS release by using an "install operation". Note that if the switch is upgraded non-disruptively, reload the switch once for the new BIOS to take effect.If an upgrade cannot be performed immediately, contact the Technical Assistance Center (TAC) in order to load a debugging plugin. This grants access to the Linux shell where the ports can be temporarily blocked via the CLI. Note that this workaround does not survive a reload, and the NX-OS upgrade is suggested as a long-term fix.Use the following table to determine the NX-OS upgrade path to an appropriate Fixed-In NX-OS release.Impacted NX-OS ReleaseFixed-In NX-OS Release7.0(7) and prior7.0(8)N1(1)7.1(x)7.1(4)N1(1)7.2(x)7.3(0)N1(1), 7.3(1)N1(1) This table details the fixed BIOS versions per platformPLATFORMFIXED BIOS VERSION for 7.0(8)N1(1) and 7.3(0)N1(1)FIXED BIOS VERSION for 7.1(4)N1(1) and 7.3(1)N1(1)Nexus 56241.1.31.1.6Nexus 56481.1.41.1.7Nexus 5672UP2.1.52.1.7Nexus 5672UP-16G0.1.60.2.0*Nexus 56962.3.02.6.0Nexus 561283.3.03.7.0Nexus 60012.2.02.5.0*Nexus 5672UP-16G is only supported in 7.3 releases If it has been determined that the error symptoms are due to a hardware component failure, contact the Technical Assistance Center (TAC) or your Account Team to request a hardware replacement.
data.caveat: Automated matching is only on PID.  Manual verification of software version will be required.

data.bulletinTitle: FN64117 - A9K-8X100G and A9K-4X100G Line Cards Might Experience a Power Sequencer Failure in Certain ASR-9922 Configurations - Software Upgrade Recommended
data.problemDescription: The Tomahawk line cards might experience a cooling issue when installed in an ASR-9922 chassis, which results in a line card failure/shutdown with this syslog error message:RP/0/RP0/CPU0:Feb 25 00:44:57.277 GMT: canb-server[152]: %PLATFORM-CANB_SERVER-7-CBC_PRE_RESET_NOTIFICATION : Node 0/0/CPU0 , Power Sequencer Failure (0x09000000)This syslog error message is a high level error message which can be triggered for different reasons. If this error message is triggered and these three conditions are met you might encounter this problem:1. The chassis is an ASR-9922.2. An A9K and A99 8X100GE and/or A9K-4X100GE line card is deployed in the ASR-9922 chassis.3. The chassis runs with a fan speed of approximately 3600 RPM.Example of a Syslog Message Where This Issue Is Not HitIf the syslog error message listed in the Problem Description section is seen after a router reload, a line card reset, or Software Maintenance Upgrade (SMU) and the A9K A99 8X100GE and/or A9K-4X100GE line cards have booted up normally, the line cards are most likely "not" affected.
data.background: Fans in the ASR-9922 router that run at default speed might not provide sufficient airflow to the Tomahawk (A9K and A99 8X100GE-xx and A9K-4X100GE-xx) line cards. As a result, the power brick on these line cards might operate at a temperature higher than recommended which could lead to a line card failure (shut down). This issue is applicable only if all of these conditions are met: 1. The chassis is an ASR-9922.2. An A9K-8X100GE and/or A9K-4X100GE line card is deployed in the ASR-9922 chassis.3. The chassis runs with a fan speed of approximately 3600 RPM.4. Line card failure/shutdown occurs with this syslog error message: RP/0/RP0/CPU0:Feb 25 00:44:57.277 GMT: canb-server[152]: %PLATFORM-CANB_SERVER-7-CBC_PRE_RESET_NOTIFICATION : Node 0/0/CPU0 , Power Sequencer Failure (0x09000000)
data.problemSymptoms: The A9K and A99 8X100GE-xx and/or A9K-4X100GE-xx line cards might fail (shut down) with this syslog error message:RP/0/RP0/CPU0:Feb 25 00:44:57.277 GMT: canb-server[152]: %PLATFORM-CANB_SERVER-7-CBC_PRE_RESET_NOTIFICATION : Node 0/0/CPU0 , Power Sequencer Failure (0x09000000)
data.workaround: If you run an ASR-9922 with A9K or A99 8X100GE and/or A9K-4X100GE line card(s), the steps in this section should be performed.If the A9K and A99 8X100GE or A9K-4X100GE line card fails/shuts down with the previously listed error message, return the failed line card on a Return Material Authorization (RMA) and install the SMU before you install the replacement line card.In order to prevent potential failures, Cisco recommends to immediately install the appropriate SMU. If you are unable to immediately install the SMU, complete these steps in order to reconfigure the FAN speed via the Altitude setting:Important Note:The altitude reconfiguration must be removed before you install the SMU.Long Term Solution: Install the production SMU.The Cisco IOS XR 6.0.1 CCO release will contain this fix, therefore the altitude reconfiguration must be removed before you upgrade to Release 6.0.1.Production SMU Availability and Installation StepsSoftwareSMU LinkAvailability5.3.1asr9k-px-5.3.1.CSCuy53875.tarCurrently Available5.3.2asr9k-px-5.3.2.CSCuy53875.tarCurrently Available5.3.3asr9k-px-5.3.3.CSCuy53875.tarCurrently Available1. Download the SMU to router.2. Enter the admin show environment fans command in order to check the FAN speed. Make a note of the FAN speed.3. Enter the admin show run  include altitude command in order to check the current altitude configuration.Current altitude config:RP/0/RSP0/CPU0:asr9k-2#admin show run  in altitudeFri Apr 15 17:44:55.713 UTCBuilding configuration...environment altitude 2000 rack 0RP/0/RSP0/CPU0:asr9k-2#4. Remove the altitude configuration (admin config no environment altitude, that is, the value from the output in the previous step).Remove altitude config:RP/0/RSP0/CPU0:asr9k-2#admin configFri Apr 15 17:45:03.509 UTCRP/0/RSP0/CPU0:asr9k-2(admin-config)#no environment altitude 2000 rack 0RP/0/RSP0/CPU0:asr9k-2(admin-config)#RP/0/RSP0/CPU0:asr9k-2(admin-config)#commitFri Apr 15 17:45:14.454 UTCRP/0/RSP0/CPU0:asr9k-2(admin-config)#endRP/0/RSP0/CPU0:asr9k-2#Verify altitude config is removed:RP/0/RSP0/CPU0:asr9k-2#admin show run  in altitudeFri Apr 15 17:45:18.116 UTCBuilding configuration...RP/0/RSP0/CPU0:asr9k-2#5. Activate the SMU.6. If the SMU fails to activate, enter the admin config environment altitude <> rack <> command in order to revert the altitude configuration (altitude value can be found in the step 3 output).7. Enter the admin show environment fans command in order to check the FAN speed after 5 to 10 minutes of SMU activation. Fan speed should be around 5400 if the ASR-9922 chassis has 8x100 or 4x100 line cards.If you are unable to immediately install the SMU, complete these steps:1. Immediately reconfigure the fan speed on the ASR-9922 router if the fan speed is less than 5400 RPM.2. Enter the admin config environment altitude command in order to set the altitude value, based on the Ambient Temperature Table shown next, on all ASR-9922 routers which have a A9K-8X100GE or A9K-4X100GE line card.Note: Altitude value is the only configurable value which has an effect on fan speed.Important Note: The altitude reconfiguration must be removed before you install the SMU.Ambient Temperature TableExample: For Ambient Temp of 30 degrees configure RP2 Altitude value to 3000 and RP1 to 1500. Ambient TemperatureAverage of Active RP inlet tempand standby RP inlet tempRecommended Altitudevalues for RP2Recommended Altitudevalues for RP1204000400021400040002240003800234000350024400032002540002900264000260027380023002835002100293200180030300015003126001200322400900332100600341800350351500100361200No Action37900No Action38600No Action39350No Action40100No ActionReconfigure Fan InstructionsApply this workaround only if the fan speed is less than 5400 RPM on the ASR-9922 router and A9K-8X100GE and/or A9K-4X100GE are installed.1. Check the current altitude configuration.RP/0/RP0/CPU0:ASR9922-B#admin show environment altitudeAltitude:*0/**/*112 meters above sea level <===== 112 metersRP/0/RP0/CPU0:ASR9922-B#2. Check the fan speed. This output shows that fan speed is around 3600 which is the lowest.RP/0/RP0/CPU0:ASR9922-B#admin show environment fans Fan speed (rpm) and run time (in hours) :FAN0 FAN1 FAN2 FAN3 FAN4 FAN5 FAN6 FAN7 FAN8 FAN9 FAN10 FAN110/FT0/* (Speed)3624 3609 3694 3568 3533 3567 3553 3403 3625 3559 3569 34070/FT0/* (Run Time)4493 4493 4493 4493 4493 4493 4493 4493 4493 4493 4493 44930/FT1/* (Speed)3719 3551 3551 3621 3563 3554 3603 3539 3536 3501 3555 35460/FT1/* (Run Time)4495 4495 4495 4495 4495 4495 4495 4495 4495 4495 4495 44950/FT2/* (Speed)3576 3593 3568 3543 3607 3562 3635 3568 3552 3540 3546 34860/FT2/* (Run Time)4494 4494 4494 4494 4494 4494 4494 4494 4494 4494 4494 44940/FT3/* (Speed)3639 3655 3565 3491 3630 3638 3561 3578 3567 3466 3568 36320/FT3/* (Run Time)4484 4484 4484 4484 4484 4484 4484 4484 4484 4484 4484 4484RP/0/RP0/CPU0:ASR9922-B#3. Configure the altitude value based on the "Ambient Temp Table" above.RP/0/RSP0/CPU0:asr9k-3#RP/0/RSP0/CPU0:asr9k-3#admin configRP/0/RSP0/CPU0:asr9k-3(admin-config)#environment altitude XXXX rack 0 (Note: XXXX is the value derived from the Ambient Temp Table above)RP/0/RSP0/CPU0:asr9k-3(admin-config)#commitRP/0/RSP0/CPU0:asr9k-3(admin-config)#endRP/0/RSP0/CPU0:asr9k-3#4. Confirm that the altitude configuration is modified.RP/0/RP0/CPU0:ASR9922-B#admin show environment altitudeMon Mar 7 11:52:57.053 UTCAltitude:*0/**/*XXXX meters above sea level <==== Value changed to what was configured in Step 3.RP/0/RP0/CPU0:ASR9922-B#5. Check the fan speed after the altitude configuration change (wait for five minutes before you check the fan RPM).RP/0/RP0/CPU0:ASR9922-B#admin show environment fans Mon Mar 7 12:05:03.612 UTCFan speed (rpm) and run time (in hours) :FAN0 FAN1 FAN2 FAN3 FAN4 FAN5 FAN6 FAN7 FAN8 FAN9 FAN10 FAN110/FT0/* (Speed)5624 5675 5657 5563 5525 5559 5542 5679 5650 5562 5594 5644 <== Speed changed from 3600 to 56000/FT0/* (Run Time)4493 4493 4493 4493 4493 4493 4493 4493 4493 4493 4493 44930/FT1/* (Speed)5533 5534 5551 5616 5581 5530 5580 5530 5657 5681 5528 55330/FT1/* (Run Time)4495 4495 4495 4495 4495 4495 4495 4495 4495 4495 4495 44950/FT2/* (Speed)5565 5576 5550 5508 5599 5546 5638 5562 5545 5519 5543 55200/FT2/* (Run Time)4494 4494 4494 4494 4494 4494 4494 4494 4494 4494 4494 44940/FT3/* (Speed)5631 5634 5547 5679 5610 5640 5544 5500 5535 5656 5568 56200/FT3/* (Run Time)4485 4485 4485 4485 4485 4485 4485 4485 4485 4485 4485 4485RP/0/RP0/CPU0:ASR9922-B#

data.bulletinTitle: FN64125 - In Some Nexus 5672, 56128, and 5696 Switches, Nondisruptive ISSUs Might Fail and Require Manual Intervention for System Recovery - Workaround Provided
data.problemDescription: Nexus 5672, 5696, and 56128 Series switches which have a VIKING USB device can fail during a nondisruptive in-service software upgrade (ISSU) and require manual intervention in order to recover the system.
data.background:
Nexus 5672, 5696, and 56128 Series switches which have a VIKING USB device can fail during a nondisruptive ISSU. Nexus 5672, 5696, and 56128 Series switches which have a UNIGEN or SMART USB device are not susceptible to the nondisruptive ISSU failure.

Refer to the "How to Identify Affected Hardware" section for details on how to determine the manufacturer of the switch USB device. Disruptive upgrades on the Nexus 5672, 5696, and 56128 Series switches are not impacted by this issue. Also, this issue does not apply to Nexus 5624, 5648, 600x, and 55xx Series switches.
data.problemSymptoms:
If a nondisruptive ISSU is performed on a switch which has a VIKING USB device, the upgrade can fail and the switch will end up in boot prompt and require manual intervention in order to recover.

The output in red will be visible in the console after a failed upgrade:

<FONT face="Courier New">
N5696-1# install
.
.
.
Checking all filesystems..... done.</FONT>
<FONT face="Courier New" color="red">
##############################################################
Boot has been interrupted or internal disk is not initialized!
##############################################################
Do you want to initialize it? (y/n) n
INIT: 
INIT: Sending processes the TERM signal
INIT: Sending processes the KILL signal
Cisco Nexus Operating System (NX-OS) Software
TAC support: http://www.cisco.com/tac
Copyright (c) 2002-2015, Cisco Systems, Inc. All rights reserved.
The copyrights to certain works contained in this software are
owned by other third parties and used and distributed under
license. Certain components of this software are licensed under
the GNU General Public License (GPL) version 2.0 or the GNU
Lesser General Public License (LGPL) Version 2.1. A copy of each
such license is available at
http://www.opensource.org/licenses/gpl-2.0.php and
http://www.opensource.org/licenses/lgpl-2.1.php
switch(boot)# dir
 
Usage for bootflash: filesystem 
   96215040 bytes used
  323215360 bytes free
  419430400 bytes total
switch(boot)# </FONT>
data.workaround: Upgrade Failure Recovery If a switch is already in a failed state, enter the reload command in the console session in order to recover. The reload boots the switch with the new NX-OS. switch(boot)# reload Proactive Workarounds - If a nondisruptive ISSU is not a requirement, perform a disruptive upgrade with the hidden force installer option. Example: N5696-1# install all kickstart bootflash:n6000-uk9-kickstart.7.0.7.N1.1.bin system bootflash:n6000-uk9.7.0.7.N1.1.bin force - If a nondisruptive ISSU is a requirement, there is a debug plugin and potential BIOS update which can be implemented prior to initiation of each nondisruptive ISSU. Contact the Cisco Technical Assistance Center (TAC) for assistance with this option.
data.caveat: Mapping is only based on PID.  For additional information, see the Field Notice bulletin.

data.bulletinTitle: FN64127 - CRS-X Line Cards with New DRAM Fail to Boot to XR-Run State - Software Upgrade Recommended
data.problemDescription: CRS-X line cards (CRS-MSC-X, CRS-MSC400G, CRS-FP-X, CRS-FP400G=, CRS-FP400G, CRS-LSP-X, CRS-LSP400G, CRS-MSC-X-L, CRS-MSC200G=, CRS-FP-X-L, CRS-FP200G, CRS-FP200G-L, and CRS-FP200G=) built with new DRAM memory fail to boot to the XR-Run state in XR releases of 5.3.3, 5.1.4, 5.1.3, 5.3.1, 5.3.2, 5.1.1, 5.1.2 and 5.3.4.
data.background:
In the manufacture of line cards CRS-MSC-X, CRS-MSC400G, CRS-FP-X, CRS-FP400G=, CRS-FP400G, CRS-LSP-X, CRS-LSP400G, CRS-MSC-X-L,	CRS-MSC200G=, CRS-FP-X-L, CRS-FP200G, CRS-FP200G-L, and CRS-FP200G=, it is required to use a new DRAM memory since the existing one is End of Life. 

It was found that this new DRAM memory on the board fails to boot up due to Network Processor Unit (NPU) driver initialization errors. The unit requires a reload Software Maintenance Upgrade (SMU) in order to make the boards work properly.
data.problemSymptoms:
The line card fails to boot to the XR-Run state. The unit goes for continuous reload and reaches the IN-Reset state.

The sample logs as the signature of this issue on XR 533 release are:

Reboot reason:

'NPU initialization failed'

The sample syslogs for issue symptoms are: 

LC/0/2/CPU0:Mar 10 06:33:35.070 : npu_driver[271]: %L2-NPU-2-DRAM_INIT_FAILURE : NPU_INST 0: DRAM instance 10 initialization failed for memory type PBS at the phase control init
LC/0/2/CPU0:Mar 10 06:33:46.417 : npu_driver[271]: %L2-NPU-2-DRAM_INIT_FAILURE : NPU_INST 0: DRAM instance 10 initialization failed for memory type PBS at the phase final
LC/0/2/CPU0:Mar 10 06:33:51.144 : npu_driver[271]: %L2-NPU-3-ERROR_MSG : *** NPU0: FATAL error at {line:831}: failure in GIF block, rc=-1463657962, 'NPU Driver' detected the 'fatal' condition 'at hw lib layer: Internal object': Invalid argument
LC/0/2/CPU0:Mar 10 06:33:51.145 : npu_driver[271]: %L2-NPU-3-INIT_ERROR_MSG : NPU0: Init Failed. Caused by:'NPU Driver' detected the 'fatal' condition 'at hw lib layer: Internal object': Invalid argument
LC/0/2/CPU0:Mar 10 06:33:51.145 : npu_driver[271]: %L2-NPU-3-ERR_EXIT : Exit on error: Failed asic power-on reset init: Caused by 'NPU Driver' detected the 'fatal' condition 'at hw lib layer: Internal object': Invalid argument  : pkg/bin/npu_driver : (PID=106555) :  -Traceback= 420956c 420a14c 421071a df6996e cb84050
LC/0/2/CPU0:Mar 10 06:33:51.979 : npu_driver[271]: %L2-NPU-6-INFO_MSG : NPU0: *** Total Valid NPUs:2 (max=2) ***
