data.bulletinTitle: FN64175 - Catalyst 2960X and 6800IA Units Might Display Error on HW Authenticity or Uplink Ports Might Fail Intermittently - Software Upgrade Recommended
data.problemDescription: Catalyst 2960X/XR switches and Catalyst 6800IA/FEX as listed in the Products Affected section might exhibit any of these errors when you insert a stack module with stack cable:  Uplink interfaces might occasionally fail Small Form-Factor Pluggable (SFP) might report as Unknown Software might report the switch hardware is not authentic Redundant Power Supply (RPS) might not respond  Catalyst 2960X/6800IA platforms with GLC-T or selected SFPs plugged into uplink ports are affected and this issue might also occasionally appear without SFP/GLC-T.
data.background: This issue is seen in the previously mentioned Catalyst 2960X/2960XR platforms that run software earlier than version 15.2(2)E4 and 6800IA platform that run software earlier than version 15.1(2)SY5.
data.problemSymptoms: One of these symptoms might be seen:  When the uplink goes down, the show idprom command shows this  error:  hulc_sfp_iic_intf_read_eeprom sfp _index 3 yeti_iic_read_retry fail After the switch reloads, the switch or the stack module might fail device authentication with either of these error messages:  For stack module authentication failure: "%ILET-1-DEVICE_AUTHENTICATION_FAIL" -  The FlexStack module inserted in this switch might not have been manufactured by Cisco or with Cisco's authorization. If your use of this product is the cause of a support issue, Cisco might deny operation of the product and support under your warranty or under a Cisco technical support program such as Smart Net. Contact Cisco's Technical Assistance Center (TAC) for more information. For switch authentication failure: "%ILET-1-AUTHENTICATION_FAIL" -  This switch might not have been manufactured by Cisco or with Cisco's authorization. This product might contain software that was copied in violation of Cisco's license terms. If your use of this product is the cause of a support issue, Cisco might deny operation of the product and  support under your warranty or under a Cisco technical support program such as Smart Net. Contact Cisco's TAC for more information. The RPS is declared as not responding with this error message:PLATFORM_ENV-1-RPS_ACCESS: RPS is not responding
data.workaround: For C2960X switches Check the software version.  If you have a version earlier than Version 15.0(2a)EX5, upgrade to Version 15.0(2a)EX5 or later. Versions 15.2(2)E4 and later are recommended. If you already upgraded to Version 15.0(2a)EX5 or later, remove all the power cables and connect them back in order to hard reset (power cycle) the device.  If the issue still persists after an upgrade/hard reset or if there is a RPS in the system and it does not respond, upgrade to Version 15.2(2)E4.Note: When you upgrade a switch from EX releases to Version 15.2(2)E4, always perform a hard reset.For C6800IA switches Check the software version. If you have a version earlier than Version 15.1.2-SY5, upgrade to Version 15.1.2-SY5 or later. Version 15.2(1)SY2 and later are recommended. If you already upgraded to Version 15.1.2-SY5 or later, remove all the power cables and connect them back in order to hard reset (power cycle) the device.Note: When you upgrade a switch, always perform a hard reset.
data.caveat: Mapping is based on PID only.  Manual verification of software version will be required.

data.bulletinTitle: FN64178 - N2K-C2232TM-E FEX 10G Port Speed Auto-Negotiation Failure - Replace on Failure
data.problemDescription: 10G capable devices auto-negotiate to 1G when connected to Nexus 2232TM-E FEX. Some devices also exhibit non-stomped cyclic redundancy check (CRC) errors RX into the FEX ports while in 10G mode.
data.background: High ripple noise to the 10G PHY, caused by part-to-part variation in the 2232TM-E FEX, results in some ports that fail to negotiate to 10G. This issue is NOT seen on all 2232TM-E FEX units and manifests over time in as little as a few weeks of FEX operation. If the FEX hits Cisco bug ID CSCux14029, a FEX reload has no positive impact on port speed negotiation. THESE PRODUCTS ARE IMPACTED BY THIS ISSUE: N2K-C2232TM-E, N2K-C2232TM-E-10GE, and N2K-C2232TM-E-10G= with any of these Hardware Versions: 1.0, 1.1, 2.0, 2.1, 2.2, or 2.3. N2K-C2232TM-E, N2K-C2232TM-E-10GE, and N2K-C2232TM-E-10G= products with a Hardware Version 3.0 or later are NOT impacted.
data.problemSymptoms: The problem symptoms are: - All or some ports on the FEX fail to negotiate to 10G. Ports will negotiate to 1G. Port negotiated at 1G: esc-6004-A# show interface Ethernet 161/1/1-32 brief | inc up Eth161/1/12 1 eth access up none 1000(D) -- esc-6004-A# Port negotiated at 10G: esc-6004-A# show interface Ethernet 161/1/1-32 brief | inc up Eth161/1/12 1 eth access up none 10G(D) -- esc-6004-A# - Non-stomped CRC errors seen on the 2232TM-E FEX while in 10G mode. Sample output of the show RMON command is shown here: esc-6004-A# show platform software woodside rmon 0 hi3 . . . 161/1/1-32 brief | inc up | | | | RX_CRC_NOT_STOMPED | 843746| 2000| esc-6004-A# Note: If you see CRC non-stomped errors, you will also see output as shown in the next sample for all ports that do see CRC errors in the woodside dbg logs. Sample output of the woodside dbgexec show log command is shown here: esc-6004-A# dbgexec woo show log 07/17/2017 22:45:36.590434 |t| 0-HI3 : PORT:EMI RETRAIN INFO 07/17/2017 22:45:36.590533 |t| 0-HI3 : PORT:EMI RETRAIN INFO: Frequency of the most successful recent retrain = 1382417209800994901086282264912424104663336231431007581000376674887895746384644 07/17/2017 22:45:36.590891 |t| 0-HI7 : PORT:EMI RETRAIN INFO: MDI Pair Diff tone levels (uV) estimated on pair A = 0 07/17/2017 22:45:36.590959 |t| 0-HI3 : PORT:EMI RETRAIN INFO: MDI Pair Diff tone levels (uV) estimated on pair B = 0 07/17/2017 22:45:36.591038 |t| 0-HI3 : PORT:EMI RETRAIN INFO: MDI Pair Diff tone levels (uV) estimated on pair C = 0 07/17/2017 22:45:36.591096 |t| 0-HI3 : PORT:EMI RETRAIN INFO: MDI Pair Diff tone levels (uV) estimated on pair D = 0 07/17/2017 22:45:36.591148 |t| 0-HI : PORT:EMI RETRAIN INFO: SNR (dB) of pair A = 138241720980099490108628226491242410466333623143100758100037667488789574638464411125328654128836478841694187 07/17/2017 22:45:36.591487 |t| 0-HI7 : PORT:EMI RETRAIN INFO: SNR (dB) of pair B = 138241720980099490108628226491242410466333623143100758100037667488789574638464411125328654128836478841694187 07/17/2017 22:45:36.591834 |t| 0-HI7 : PORT:EMI RETRAIN INFO: SNR (dB) of pair C = 138241720980099490108628226491242410466333623143100758100037667488789574638464411125328654128836478841694187 07/17/2017 22:45:36.592192 |t| 0-HI7 : PORT:EMI RETRAIN INFO: SNR (dB) of pair D = 138241720980099490108628226491242410466333623143100758100037667488789574638464411125328654128836478841694187 07/17/2017 22:45:36.592549 |t| 0-HI7 : PORT:END OF EMI RETRAIN INFO esc-6004-A# - Moving the network cable to a non-impacted 2232TM-E FEX brings the link up at 10G.
data.workaround: Verify the current port speed. If the speed is reported as 1G, move the network cable to a port on FEX known to negotiate to 10G. If the port comes up as 10G, then the prior FEX is probably impacted by Cisco bug ID CSCux14029. Verify the FEX Hardware Version per the instructions in the "How to Identify Hardware Levels" section. If the unit has an impacted Hardware Version, contact your Cisco Sales or Account representative in order to request a replacement.

data.bulletinTitle: FN64180 - Nexus 55xx, 56xx, and 600x Series Switch Platforms SNMPd process restart when process reaches Memory Threshold - Software Upgrade Recommended
data.problemDescription: The Cisco Nexus 55xx, 56xx, and 600x Series Switches that run certain NX-OS System Software versions can encounter a reset in the Simple Network Management Protocol daemon (SNMPd) process when the process reaches the memory threshold.
data.background:
The memory that is held by the SNMPd process under the libport_mgr_common module increases over time if the SNMP applications continuously send SNMPget requests on the entSensorThresholdSeverity [1.3.6.1.4.1.9.9.91.1.2.1.1.2] object. If the memory utilization of the libport_mgr_common module reaches 250 MB, the SNMPd process restarts.

You can enter this command in order to monitor the current memory utilization of the libport_mgr_common module:

esc-6004-A# show system internal snmp mem-stats detail | grep libport
 102 [r-xp]/isan/plugin/0/isan/lib/libport_m 509002 509003  253991998  253992437
esc-6004-A#

This issue is applicable to the Nexus switch platforms that are listed in the Products Affected section of this document that run these versions of the NX-OS System Software:

  • 7.1(0)N1(1a)
  • 7.1(1)N1(1b)
  • 7.1(1)N1(1)
  • 7.1(2)N1(1)
  • 7.1(3)N1(1)
  • 7.1(3)N1(2)
  • 7.2(0)N1(1)
  • 7.2(1)N1(1)

Note: The Cisco Nexus 55xx, 56xx, and 600x Series Switch platforms that run NX-OS System Software Versions 7.0(x) and earlier are not affected.
data.problemSymptoms:
If the libport_mgr_common module memory utilization reaches 250 MB, the switch encounters a reset in the SNMPd process:

2016 Jun 10 02:20:16 N6001 %ETHPORT-5-SPEED: Interface Ethernet2/8,
 operational speed changed to 1 Gbps
2016 Jun 10 02:20:16 N6001 %ETHPORT-5-IF_DUPLEX: Interface Ethernet2/8,
 operational duplex mode changed to Full
2016 Jun 10 02:20:16 N6001 %ETHPORT-5-IF_RX_FLOW_CONTROL: Interface Ethernet2/8,
 operational Receive Flow Control state changed to off
2016 Jun 10 02:20:16 N6001 %ETHPORT-5-IF_TX_FLOW_CONTROL: Interface Ethernet2/8,
 operational Transmit Flow Control state changed to off
2016 Jun 10 02:20:16 N6001 %ETHPORT-5-IF_UP: Interface Ethernet2/8
 is up in mode trunk
2016 Jun 10 03:35:21 N6001 %SYSMGR-2-SERVICE_CRASHED: Service "snmpd" (PID 28063)
 hasn't caught signal 11 (core will be saved).
2016 Jun 10 11:41:28 N6001 %SYSMGR-2-SERVICE_CRASHED: Service "snmpd" (PID 12855)
 hasn't caught signal 11 (core will be saved).
data.workaround:
In order to resolve this issue, use SNMPwalk instead of SNMPget when you poll for the entSensorThresholdSeverity [1.3.6.1.4.1.9.9.91.1.2.1.1.2] object. Alternatively, you can upgrade the NX-OS System Software to one of these versions:

  • 7.0(x) and earlier
  • 7.1(4)N1(1) and later
  • 7.3(0)N1(1) and later

data.bulletinTitle: FN64185 - Cisco Phone 8831 - DECT Compliance Issue in Select Markets Outside North America - Replace on Failure
data.problemDescription: Some Cisco Phone 8831 base units were shipped to regions outside North America with the Digital Enhanced Cordless Telecommunications (DECT) radio setting configured to a frequency for North America. In markets where DECT radios are not permitted, this could mean that the devices are not compliant. Dependent upon their location, affected users might need to permanently disable the DECT radio on the CP-8831 base, configure their device to the appropriate frequency, or replace the device with a No Radio (NR) version.
data.background: Regional variants were developed for Europe(EU)and other regions. Dependent upon the local regulations, users in these markets with DECT "Radio On" units shipped before the availability of the NR model might need to: - Download CP-8831-NR firmware in order to disable DECT permanently, or - Configure their device to the appropriate frequency In regions of the world where DECT is not compliant at any frequency, such as China, Brazil, and India, an NR version of the Cisco CP-8831 is now orderable and available worldwide. With the CP-8831 NR version, the DECT radio hardware is physically present on the printed circuit board (PCB), but disabled by the firmware. No firmware can be loaded onto the NR version of the 8831 that will enable the DECT radio. The end-user or system integrator will be unable to power the radio in order to ensure it is compliant. For additional details and regional product IDs, see Field Notice Number 63899, titled CP-8831 Radio Frequency Issue - Upgrade Needed.
data.problemSymptoms: The issue will not affect operation, but affected customers' need to comply with regulatory requirements in the country or region where their CP-8831 units are located.
data.workaround: These products are available in which the DECT radio has been disabled: - CP-8831-NR-K9= (Base plus DCU) - CP-8831-BASE-S-NR (Base only) - CP-8831-DC-NR-K9= (Daisy Chain Kit) End-customers located in regions where DECT is prohibited and already own a CP-8831 with DECT can contact the Technical Assistance Center (TAC) and request the CP-8831-NR firmware version. Important Note: Once the CP-8831-NR firmware version has been downloaded, the CP-8831 cannot be returned to DECT capabilities. Customers who have the NR version of the 8831 can use the wired extension microphones and the Daisy Chain unit in order to extend the audio reach of their Cisco 8831. For those customers who are unable to reach the TAC, contact 8831-radiofrequency@cisco.com for additional instructions.

data.bulletinTitle: FN64190 - Cisco IOS XE - Show commands on Cisco IOS XE based platforms might not report true platform memory usage - Software Upgrade Recommended
data.problemDescription: The show command on Cisco IOS XE based products might not report true platform memory usage.
data.background: On products that run Cisco IOS XE (see the Products Affected section), the Linux kernel uses free memory space in order to expand its cache. This results in the free memory space to decrease over time and might appear as if the router experiences a memory leak. This could be a false alarm since the cache can be freed if memory is needed.
data.problemSymptoms: When you use the command show platform software status control-processor, over time the free memory might display a smaller percentage as shown in this example highlighted in bold.  Memory (kB) Slot Status Total Used (Pct) Free (Pct) Committed (Pct) RP0 Healthy 3972008 3942316 (99%) 29692 ( 1%) 2392632 (60%)
data.workaround: There is one solution and two workarounds.  The solution is to upgrade to Cisco IOS XE Denali 16.3.  Workaround 1 In order to obtain a good estimate of free memory, enter the command monitor platform software process rp active:  top - 17:02:19 up 26 days, 22:52,  0 users,  load average: 0.00, 0.00, 0.00 Tasks: 445 total, 1 running, 444 sleeping, 0 stopped, 0 zombie Cpu(s): 0.8% us, 1.7% sy, 0.0% ni, 97.5% id, 0.0% wa, 0.0% hi, 0.0% si, 0.0% st Mem: 3972008k total, 3946308k used, 25700k free, 223416k buffers Swap: 0k total, 0k used, 0k free, 1537140k cached  In order to estimate the free memory, add free + buffers + cached memory. From the previous example, the estimated free memory is 25700k + 223416k + 1537140k = 1786256k. This indicates that the estimated free memory is 45% of the total memory.  Workaround 2  This example lists the steps to be followed in order to get accurate used and free memory on an active Route Processor (RP).  Note: Use of the sync command might increase CPU utilization of the RP.          Obtain a one day platform shell license. See Product License Registration. This requires a CCO account.Install the shell license obtained in Step 1.Enter the config command platform shell.Enter the exec command request platform software system shell rp active. This results in a platform shell prompt.At the platform shell prompt, enter y.At the shell prompt, enter sync;echo 3 > /proc/sys/vm/drop_caches.Exit the platform shell.Enter the command show platform software status control-processor.  This displays an accurate value for used and free memory using show platform software status control-processor and querying the SNMP MIB browser in order to decipher memory usage.  Free memory - 1.3.6.1.4.1.9.9.109.1.1.1.1.13 Used memory - 1.3.6.1.4.1.9.9.109.1.1.1.1.12

data.bulletinTitle: FN64191 - Catalyst 3850/3650 Switches That Run Cisco IOS XE Releases 3.6.5E/3.7.4E or Earlier Might Exhibit High CPU Usage - Workaround Provided
data.problemDescription: Catalyst 3850 and Catalyst 3650 switches as listed above may report unexpected high CPU usage, despite any changes made to the configuration or network traffic inbound or outbound to the switch. One of the cores may exhibit high CPU usage due to either of the below process/threads, however CPU-bound traffic continues to be processed using the remaining cores.-FED/fed-ots-main-FED/Punject Rx-stack-mgr/Replenish OOB-stack-mgr/OOBnd RX
data.background: High CPU usage may occur on Catalyst 3850 and Catalyst 3650 switches that have long runtime (several months)
data.problemSymptoms: Following commands will show one or more cores high CPU at 90% or above consistently.1. show processes cpu sort Below is the example of the output of the above command 2. show processes cpu detailed process [process-name] sorted ...........The following [process-name]s are known to have contributed to this problem: ................fed/fed-ots-main ................fed/punject rx ................stack-mgr/Replenish oob ................stack-mgr/oobnd rx Below is the example of the output of the above command
data.workaround: If the switch shows high CPU usage, please take necessary steps as mentioned in below table

data.bulletinTitle: FN64197 - WAAS Devices That Run 6.1.1, 6.1.1a, or 6.2.1 Might Have Connections Reset  - Software Upgrade Recommended
data.problemDescription:
After six to eight weeks of system uptime, Cisco Wide Area Application Services (WAAS) devices that run Software Version 6.1.1, 6.1.1a, or 6.2.1 start to retransmit packets quickly between peers. Due to issues with the timer scheduler, timers misfire before their scheduled times. This results in immediate retransmissions of TCP packets and might cause connection resets.

When this condition is triggered, traffic on the WAN increases. Not all connections might fail during this condition, but this can cause a network outage.
data.background: 6.1.1, 6.1.1a, and 6.2.1 WAAS software timer scheduler compares the current and scheduled times and incorrectly determines that all the scheduled timers have elapsed. All the timers are then executed without delay.
data.problemSymptoms: Access to WAAS devices will be very slow due to the access link congested by the fast retransmission of the packets. Central Manager will report optimized traffic volume much greater than the original traffic.
data.workaround: In order to correct this issue, complete these steps: 1. Reboot the WAAS devices - the problem will likely recur after a similar time has elapsed. 2. Upgrade to WAAS 6.2.1a or later (recommended). WAAS software can be found on the WAAS Download Software page.

data.bulletinTitle: FN64199 - Cisco 7962 / 7965 / 7975 - SCCP Phones with Expansion Modules are Resetting - Software Upgrade Recommended
data.problemDescription:
Cisco 7962, 7965 or 7975 Skinny Client Control Protocol (SCCP) IP phones with expansion modules may reset. 
The reset may occur on phones that are running any firmware between 9.3(1)ES27 through 9.4(2) ES10.
data.background:
Bug CSCuu49765 - IP Phones with side cars resetting - was found in software codes 9.3(1)ES27 through 9.4(2) ES10.  

A fix was introduced in software code 9.4(2)SR2.
data.problemSymptoms: 7962, 7965 or 7975 SCCP IP phone and expansion module will reset.
data.workaround: It is recommended that customers experiencing the resets upgrade to 9.4(2)SR2 by downloading from the Download Software page Release notes can be found here

data.bulletinTitle: FN64208 - Limited Number of UCS-C3X60-SVRN Server Nodes At Risk for Early Failure - Replace on Failure
data.problemDescription: The system boards on a limited number of server nodes (SVRNs) have manufacturing issues. These boards are susceptible to failure.
data.background: There was a temporary manufacturing process issue with the fabrication of the main board.
data.problemSymptoms: The impacted SVRNs might no longer work.
data.workaround: Complete the instructions in the How to Identify Hardware Levels section in order to retrieve the serial number for your SVRN(s). Use the Serial Number Validation tool in order to verify that your product is affected.  If the unit is affected, use the process described in the Upgrade Program section of this Field Notice to order a replacement for the affected hardware.  Important: For every SVRN that needs to be replaced, you MUST also request the Pick-and-place tool (UCS-CPU-EP-PNP=), grease (UCS-CPU-GREASE3=), and cleaning kit (UCSX-HSCK=).  Replacement Procedures  Once the replacement bare SVRN has arrived, the memory and CPU must be moved from the original system to the new SVRN. Additionally, you will need to move the Host Bus Adapter (HBA) or Redundant Array of Independent Disks (RAID) controller from the old system and run the Host Upgrade Utility (HUU) in order to flash the Baseboard Management Controller (BMC) and BIOS firmware to the same version as before the replacement.  For details on how to replace the SVRN, see  "Replacing a Drive Expander Module" in the Cisco UCS C3260 Storage Server Installation and Service Guide.  For details on how to use the HUU, see "Upgrading the Firmware on a Cisco UCS C-Series Server Using the HUU" in the Cisco Host Upgrade Utility 2.0(7) User Guide."  Field Engineer Requests  If you require a Field Engineer to replace your SVRN(s), send an email to FE-req-FN64208@cisco.com with this information and format AFTER you receive your parts:   Subject: On Site FE Requested for FN64208  Requestor's CCO ID to use (if you wish to track this request) Site Information Site/Company Name Address Site Contact Telephone Email Manned site: [Yes / No] Site Security Requirements (enter any special site security requirements) What time is the requested time for Field Engineer arrival (enter local date and time) System information Hostnames/locations of servers Server models Cisco Integrated Management Controller (CIMC) version Any special Field Engineer Instructions (enter any special instructions here)   All information is required except for the CCO ID.  Note that only two server nodes can be upgraded per visit. All requests must be at least three days in advance of the requested service time.

data.bulletinTitle: FN64210 - APIC-L2/M2 Server Network Mode Set Incorrectly - Configuration Change Recommended
data.problemDescription: Cisco has recently identified a defect in the Cisco Application Centric Infrastructure (ACI) that could potentially affect customers who run these Cisco Application Policy Infrastructure Controller (APIC) appliances:Server - APIC-Cluster-L2Server - APIC-Cluster-M2Server - APIC-L2Server - APIC-M2Server - APIC-Server-L2Server - APIC-Server-M2The APIC-L2/M2 server Cisco Integrated Management Controller (CIMC) network mode was set to Shared_Lom_ext mode instead of Dedicated mode. APIC servers have a default requirement to set the network mode to Dedicated mode, or it can be reconfigured to Shared_Lom mode which is also supported. Shared_Lom_ext mode is incorrect and this setting causes some issues in the network connectivity and discovery does not function.
data.background: In a short time span in Cisco manufacturing the network mode was being set to Shared_Lom_ext mode, not the correct setting of Dedicated mode.
data.problemSymptoms: Network connectivity issues will occur and discovery will not function.
data.workaround: APIC servers with an incorrect CIMC network mode can be reconfigured to Dedicated mode or Shared_Lom mode through the CLI or GUI. Complete these steps in order to reconfigure the CIMC mode to Dedicated mode:Make sure that there is a cable connected to the CIMC MGMT port in addition to the Ethernet ports on the motherboard (LOM).Power up the unit and log in with your username and password.Enter these commands from the CIMC prompt:C240-FCH1844V103 /cimc/network # set mode dedicatedWarning: Invalid combination of "mode" and "redundancy""redundancy" is set to "active-active" but valid value(s) include: "none"Enabling auto-negotiation by default.C240-FCH1844V103 /cimc/network *# set redundancy noneC240-FCH1844V103 /cimc/network *# commitChanges to the network settings will be applied immediately.You may lose connectivity to the Cisco IMC and may have to log in again.Do you wish to continue? [y/N] yC240-FCH1844V103 /cimc/network #C240-FCH1844V103 /cimc/network # show detail  no-moreNetwork Setting:IPv4 Enabled: yesIPv4 Address: 10.1.1.34IPv4 Netmask: 255.255.255.0IPv4 Gateway: 10.1.1.11DHCP Enabled: yesDDNS Enabled: yesDDNS Update Domain:Obtain DNS Server by DHCP: yesPreferred DNS: 0.0.0.0Alternate DNS: 0.0.0.0IPv6 Enabled: noIPv6 Address: ::IPv6 Prefix: 64IPv6 Gateway: ::IPv6 Link Local: ::IPv6 SLAAC Address: ::IPV6 DHCP Enabled: noIPV6 Obtain DNS Server by DHCP: noIPV6 Preferred DNS: ::IPV6 Alternate DNS: ::VLAN Enabled: noVLAN ID: 1VLAN Priority: 0Port Profile:Hostname: C240-FCH1844V103MAC Address: A0:EC:F9:39:16:6ANIC Mode: dedicatedNIC Redundancy: noneVIC Slot: riser1Auto Negotiate: yesAdmin Network Speed: autoAdmin Duplex: autoOperational Network Speed: 100MbpsOperational Duplex: fullC240-FCH1844V103 /cimc/network # show  grep NICC240-FCH1844V103 /cimc/network # show detail  grep NICNIC Mode: dedicatedNIC Redundancy: noneC240-FCH1844V103 /cimc/network #Complete these steps in order to reconfigure the CIMC mode to Shared_Lom mode:Power up the unit and log in with your username and password.Enter these commands from the CIMC prompt:C240-FCH1844V103 /cimc/network # set mode shared_lomC240-FCH1844V103 /cimc/network *# commitChanges to the network settings will be applied immediately.You may lose connectivity to the Cisco IMC and may have to log in again.Do you wish to continue? [y/N] yC240-FCH1844V103 /cimc/network # show detail  no-moreNetwork Setting:IPv4 Enabled: yesIPv4 Address: 10.1.1.34IPv4 Netmask: 255.255.255.0IPv4 Gateway: 10.1.1.11DHCP Enabled: yesDDNS Enabled: yesDDNS Update Domain:Obtain DNS Server by DHCP: yesPreferred DNS: 0.0.0.0Alternate DNS: 0.0.0.0IPv6 Enabled: noIPv6 Address: ::IPv6 Prefix: 64IPv6 Gateway: ::IPv6 Link Local: ::IPv6 SLAAC Address: ::IPV6 DHCP Enabled: noIPV6 Obtain DNS Server by DHCP: noIPV6 Preferred DNS: ::IPV6 Alternate DNS: : :VLAN Enabled: noVLAN ID: 1VLAN Priority: 0Port Profile:Hostname: C240-FCH1844V103MAC Address: A0:EC:F9:39:16:6ANIC Mode: shared_lomNIC Redundancy: active-activeVIC Slot: riser1Auto Negotiate: yesAdmin Network Speed: autoAdmin Duplex: autoOperational Network Speed: 100MbpsOperational Duplex: fullC240-FCH1844V103 /cimc/network # show  grep NICC240-FCH1844V103 /cimc/network # show detail  grep NICNIC Mode: shared_lomNIC Redundancy: active-activeC240-FCH1844V103 /cimc/network #If you instead use the CIMC GUI, then navigate to the Admin tab in order to change the NIC Mode and NIC Redundancy as required as shown in these screenshots.Configure the CIMC Network Mode to Dedicated Mode from the GUIConfigure the CIMC Network Mode to Shared_Lom Mode from the GUI
data.caveat: Manual verification of the CIMC configuration will be required.

data.bulletinTitle: FN64211 - MDS9K - Traffic Interruption Due To Fibre Channel Interface Link Up/Down Events - Software Upgrade Recommended
data.problemDescription: In some cases the process (pmon service) responsible for the port-monitoring function on Multilayer Data Switch (MDS) Fibre Channel switching modules terminates unexpectedly. At first, this event might not cause any operational impact and the process normally restarts automatically. However, if the issue recurs multiple times it might eventually lead to severe traffic impact on the entire MDS switch. The trigger for this issue is excessive Fibre Channel interface link up/down events. At least 500 or more events have to occur before the problem occurs. Intially, the effects will be limited to the module(s) where one or more interfaces experience such events, but might later spread to the entire switch. Some common causes of link up/down events are: - Physical layer issues- Links that experience heavy congestion- Host reboots
data.background: This problem was initally identified in internal testing and is documented in Cisco bug ID CSCuz90357.
data.problemSymptoms: Dependent upon the generation of Fibre Channel switching modules used, one or more messages similar to this example might be observed in the switch syslog:# show logging log%SYSMGR-SLOT4-2-CORE_SAVE_FAILED: master_core_client_try_spawn: PID 1358 with message Unable to start core client. Cannot allocate memory. %SYSMGR-SLOT4-3-SYSMGR_CRASHED: Sysmgr (PID 1358) has terminated on receiving signal 6%PROC_MGR-SLOT1-2-ERR_MSG: ERROR: PID 1216 (pmon) killed with signal (6)%NTP-2-NTP_SYSLOG_NO_RESP_FROM_LC: from LC1 for Timestamp Update%PROC_MGR-SLOT1-4-PROC_MGR_APP_NOT_RESP: ERROR: Process (lc_port_cfg) is not responding, it will be terminated%MODULE-2-MOD_MINORSWFAIL: Module 1 (Serial number: JAF1623APRF) reported a failure in service lc_port_cfg%PROC_MGR-SLOT1-2-ERR_MSG: ERROR: PID 1181 (lc_port_cfg) killed with signal (6)One or more cores from processes pmon and/or sysmgr and/or lc_port_cfg might be present on the switch as shown in this example.# show coreModule  Instance  Process-name     PID       Date(Year-Month-Day Time)------  --------  ---------------  --------  -------------------------4       1         sysmgr           1358      2016-09-27 03:42:401       1         pmon             1216      2016-09-28 11:36:401       1         lc_port_cfg      1181      2016-09-28 16:32:03 A Fibre Channel switching module might reload or enter into the powered-dn state.
data.workaround: It is recommended that customers upgrade to MDS NX-OS Release 6.2(17) or later. NX-OS Release 6.2(17) was made available on Wednesday, July 13, 2016.If you want to run NX-OS Release 6.2(15), it is recommended that you monitor these MDS switches and ensure that there are no excessive Fibre Channel interface up/down events (500 or more).

data.bulletinTitle: FN64217 - Cisco TelePresence SX20 Quick Set with Precision 12x Camera Cable - Replace on Failure
data.problemDescription:
Cisco has found that a limited number of Cisco TelePresence SX20 Quick Set with Precision 12x Cameras were shipped with a faulty camera cable (CAB-HDMI-PHD12XS), which prevents the connected equipment from working correctly.

Cisco will replace the affected camera cables.
data.background:
Cisco has identified an assembly issue on a limited number of the camera cables used in the Cisco TelePresence SX20 Quick Set with Precision 12x Camera bundle.

Affected camera cables are limited to those produced between September 26, 2016 and October 2, 2016. They were shipped between October 6, 2016 and October 17, 2016.
data.problemSymptoms: Cisco has found that the CAB-HDMI-PHD12XS cable with Date Code: 1639 (printed on the cable plastic bag) causes a short circuit, which causes the SX20 codec to reboot continuously.
data.workaround:
Cisco recommends proactive replacement of affected cables for this issue as no workaround is available. In order to determine if the newly purchased Cisco TelePresence SX20 Quick Set with Precision 12x Camera bundle is affected, two validation options are available: Option 1
  1. Validate that the system was shipped from Cisco between October 6, 2016 and October 17, 2016. Then, enter the System Serial Number or SX20 codec Serial Number into the search box of the Cisco Serial Number Validation Tool. This tool indicates whether or not the system is affected.
  2. If the System Serial Number or SX20 codec Serial Number query result shows the status "Affected", request a cable replacement with the Cisco standard Return Material Authorization (RMA) process. If the query result shows the status "Not Affected", then no further action is required.
Option 2 Validate the date code on the plastic bag that contains the camera cable, if still available or not unpacked yet. If the label has Customer Part Number: CISH-72-5176-01 and Date Code: 1639 listed, as illustrated by the red square in the picture, then the cable is affected and should be disposed. Request a cable replacement with the Cisco standard RMA process. If the label does not have Date Code: 1639, then the cable is not affected and no further action is required.
data.caveat: Automated checks are only for the Codec Serial Number.  Any checks of the cable plastic packaging cannot be automated.

data.bulletinTitle: FN64219 - VDS-CDE250-K9 IPMI Firmware V3.09 Requires Security Enhancements-IPMI FW 3.12 Available - BIOS/Firmware Upgrade Recommended
data.problemDescription:
This Field Notice addresses two issues on the Content Delivery Engine 250 (CDE250): 

- Updates to the Intelligent Platform Management Interface (IPMI) firmware in order to remove weak ciphers from IPMI Secure Socket Shell (SSH) support.
- The current Super Doctor (SDT) utility might result in Inter-Integrated Circuit (I2C) Bus hang.
data.background:
Cipher is an algorithm used to perform encryption or decryption in the SSH protocol. The CDE250 IPMI firmware versions 3.09 and earlier have weak cipher. The CDE250 system utilizes IPMI in order to monitor and manage the health of the system. This function is implemented with embedded IPMI firmware that runs within the Baseboard Management Controller (BMC) that resides on the motherboard. The new security enhancement in IPMI version 3.12 improves the cipher.

The SDT utility versions 2.112 and earlier directly access the BMC and do not validate the I2C bus availability. This possibly causes contention issues which could result in I2C bus hang. SDT version 2.113 addresses this particular issue.
data.problemSymptoms: There is no error message for the weak cipher. This symptom can be observed for the I2C hang issue:
data.workaround:
Cisco recommends that these steps be taken in order to update the IPMI for VDS-TV, VQE, and VDS-IS applications and the SDT utility for VDS-TV and VD-IS applications. This update needs to be done during a maintenance window.
Product IDIPMI FW Version Action
CDE250-K9FW version = 3.12 or later (SDT v2.113 required)Unit is good, no action required
CDE250-K9FW version = 1.33 or 2.05 or 3.03, 3.06 or 3.09Upgrade IPMI FW
  1. Determine the IPMI FW version (see the How to Identify Hardware Levels section).
    Note: The new IPMI FW requires SDT version 2.113.
  2. If the IPMI version is not 3.12, update the IPMI FW to version 3.12 with the IPMI dedicated Ethernet port and web interface or a DOS boot stick with the IPMIUP.BAT (yafukcs -full X8DAH312.ima).
  3. Reboot the system.
  4. Verify the IPMI FW is updated successfully.
For further details, refer to the IPMI Firmware v3.12 and SDT 2.113 Upgrade instructions. For the VDS-IS application, patches have been developed in order to upgrade the SDT version 2.113 as it is required for the new IPMI FW.
VDS-IS ReleaseIPMI FW HW platformImpactActionRequired Patch
3.x3.12 and laterCDE250-K9All customers that use version 3.x up to the latest 3.3.1b138 imageApply the corresponding patch in VDS-IS to upgrade the SDT version to 2.113 IPMI_VDS-IS_3x_SDT-2.113_Patch
4.x3.12 and later CDE250-K9All customers that use version 4.x up to the latest 4.3.2-b28 imageApply corresponding patch in VDS-IS to upgrade the SDT version to 2.113IPMI_VDS-IS_4x_SDT-2.113_Patch
Update the VDS-IS Application with the Script
  1. Unzip the required IPMI_VDS-IS_3x_SDT-2.113_Patch.zip / IPMI_VDS-IS_4x_SDT-2.113_Patch.zip file.
  2. Copy all the files to the CDE250. Make sure all the files are copied to the location "local/local1".
  3. Use these commands in order to check and execute the script: script check ipmi_script.sh script execute ipmi_script.sh
  4. Once the patch is executed properly, reload the box.
Refer to the Release Notes and IPMI Firmware downloads for further details:
  • CDE250 IPMI Security Enhancement - CSCvc18598 Release Notes
  • CDE250 I2C Bus Contention - CSCve34374 Release Notes
  • IPMI firmware upgrade downloads:
    • IPMI FW v3.12 for VDS-TV Application: vdstv-ipmi312.zip
    • IPMI FW v3.12 for VQE Application: vdsvqe-ipmi312.zip
    • IPMI FW v3.12 for VDS-IS Application: vdsis-ipmi312.zip
data.caveat: Automation is only matching PID.  Manual verification of Firmware version will be required.

data.bulletinTitle: FN64225 - GLC-SX-MM-RGD and GLC-ZX-SM-RGD Modules Might Have Incompatibility Issues with CGS 2520, IE 3010, or IE2000 Switches - Replace on Failure
data.problemDescription:
A limited quantity of V02 GLC-SX-MM-RGD units shipped between late February to early September 2016 and a limited quantity of V02 GLC-ZX-SM-RGD units shipped between late April to September 2016 with serial numbers that begin with 'ACW' might have an incompatibility issue if used in CGS 2520, IE 3010, CGR-2010 GRWIC (CGS), IE2000, or IE2000U switches. 

When the issue occurs, the SFP appears inoperative and random host I2C error messages might be seen or high CPU usage until the module is removed or system power-cycled which temporarily resolves the problem.
data.background: Cisco is aware of an occurrence where this has happened in a customer environment. Only a specific combination of products and SFPs are impacted.
data.problemSymptoms:
These HARDWARE products with SFPs (GLC-SX-MM-RGD and GLC-ZX-SM-RGD) are impacted: Table 1: Impacted Platform Switches
CGS 2520 Switches IE 3010 Switches CGR-2010 GWIC(CGS) IE-2000 and IE-2000U Switches
CGS-2520-24TC,
CGS-2520-16S-8PC
IE-3010-24TC,
IE-3010-16S-8PC
GRWIC-D-ES-2S-8PC,
GRWIC-D-ES-6S
IE-2000-16PTC-G-E, IE-2000-16PTC-G-L,
IE-2000-16PTC-G-NX, IE-2000-16TC-G-E,
IE-2000-16TC-G-L, IE-2000-16TC-G-N,
IE-2000-16TC-G-X, IE-2000-4S-TS-G-B,
IE-2000-4S-TS-G-L, IE-2000-4TS-G-B,
IE-2000-4TS-G-L, IE-2000-8TC-G-B,
IE-2000-8TC-G-E, IE-2000-8TC-G-L,
IE-2000-8TC-G-N, IE-2000U-16TC-G,
IE-2000U-16TC-G-X, IE-2000U-16TC-GP,
IE-2000U-4S-G, IE-2000U-4TS-G,
IE-2000U-8TC-G
When the issue occurs, the V02 SFP (GLC-SX-MM-RGD or GLC-ZX-SM-RDG) with serial numbers that start with 'ACW' appear inoperative and random host I2C error messages might be seen or there might be high CPU usage until the module is removed or the system power-cycled which temporarily resolves the problem. Examples of error messages: - %PLATFORM_ENV-1-FRU_PS_ACCESS: FRU Power Supply is not responding (the Power Supply Unit (PSU) is OK, do NOT request a Return Material Authorization (RMA), remove the SFP) - CPU Proc = SFF8472 running way too high (~40%) %SYS-3-CPUHOG: Task is running for (2098)msecs, more than (2000)msecs (0/0),process = SFF8472. -Traceback= 0x15B0860z 0x15A967Cz 0x15A96FCz 0x167A654z 0x167C7ACz 0x167C95Cz 0x16523A0z 0x164C854z 0x16535DCz 0x1671E58z 0x1672088z 0x1177124z 0x1179C04z 0x16545ACz 0x12045E0z 0x1209420z - Console Message - hulc_sfp_iic_intf_read_eeprom sfp _index 1 yeti_iic_read_retry fail - Cisco IOS CLI - '#show int transceiver' = 'No transceiver present'
data.workaround:
Cisco will replace V02 (GLC-SX-MM-RGD and GLC-ZX-SM-RGD) parts that have 'ACW' at the start of the serial number only if it used on the switch product IDs (PIDs) referenced in the Problem Symptom section (CGS 2520, IE 3010, CGR-2010, GRWIC (CGS), IE2000, or IE2000U).

The affected hardware can be replaced through the Upgrade Program section listed in this Field Notice.

Refer to the How to Identify Hardware Levels section for instructions on how to validate impacted units.
data.caveat: Matching based on PID, Serial Number and TAN.  Manual verification of which chassis the transceiver is installed in must be done.

data.bulletinTitle: FN64226 - cBR-8-Potential Supervisor Card Reload While Running PCMM Voice and Data Traffic on Cable Modems - Software Upgrade Recommended
data.problemDescription: The Supervisor (SUP) card might reload due to a memory corruption.
data.background:
In a SUP card, certain data structures and classes are used for process execution. When a certain class target (downstream dynamic flow) is no longer used, the target class list is not erased properly. This leads to a corruption in the list queue. This issue can occur under these conditions:
  • Deletion or reset of all cable modems with the same configuration file (and thus, class parameters)
  • Shutdown of bundle, Integrated-Cable/Wideband interfaces, or MAC domain
  • Reset or removal of cBR8 line card
data.problemSymptoms: The core dump due to this issue can be diagnosed with the GDB (GNU Debugger). The crash or traceback decode points to a list operation failure due to memory corruption. Cisco Technical Support can decode the IOSD core in order to confirm that this is the root cause. Check the core file/crashinfo when the SUP protect card is back up and look for Linux-iosd core. An example is shown here: tb34-cBR8# dir stby-harddisk:core/ Directory of dir stby-harddisk:core/ 37 -rw- 1076440910 Oct 25 2016 22:40:03 -04:00 ORLD09-CTS2_RP_1_linux_iosd-imag_16167_1484784055.core.gz 7800705024 bytes total (3328479232 bytes free) tb34-cBR8#
data.workaround:
Cisco highly recommends that customers upgrade to a corresponding release that has the fix as listed in the table in this section. In the interim, and in order to avoid the SUP issue, it is suggested to not perform any of the three conditions listed in the Background section. If a SUP crash occurs, it is suggested to reload the standby SUP as well.
cBR8 IOS XE ReleaseDoes Issue Exist?Action
3.15.0SNoNone
3.16.0SYes Upgrade to 3.16.2S or later release
3.16.1SYes Upgrade to 3.16.2S or later release
3.17.0SYes Upgrade to 3.17.1S or later release
3.18.0SNoNone
3.18.0SP or newerNoNone
The show version CLI command displays the current software version that runs on the cBR8 router. See this example:
data.caveat: Automation matching on PID only.  Manual verification of software version is required.

data.bulletinTitle: FN64227 - ASA Software - Some Commands Might Fail on ASA 5500-X Security Appliances - Software Upgrade Recommended
data.problemDescription: Some versions of the Adaptive Security Appliance (ASA) software might generate an error message when certain commands are executed. This issue affects the ASA 5500-X series of security appliances.
data.background: ASA Software Releases 9.3(3), 9.4(1), 9.5(2) and 9.6(2) might generate an error message when specific memory related commands are executed. This issue affects these ASA security appliances: ASA 5506, ASA 5506H, ASA 5506W, ASA 5508, ASA 5512, ASA 5515, ASA 5516, ASA 5525, ASA 5545, and ASA 5555.
data.problemSymptoms: A summary of the ASA software commands that result in an error message are listed in this section. Other symptoms also include the failure to save the configuration to FLASH memory and the failure to save custom bookmarks to a remote server.- write memory commandASA# wrBuilding configuration...Cryptochecksum: XXXXXX%Error opening disk0:/.private/startup-config (Too many open files)Error executing command[FAILED] - disk directory commandASA# dir disk0:Directory of disk0:/%Error opening disk0:/ (Too many open files)8238202880 bytes total (4647133184 bytes free) - flash fsck commandASA# fsck flash:ERROR: There are one or more sw-modules running on the system. Please shut down the sw-modules before attempting to run fsck on flash.
data.workaround: Upgrade the ASA to one of these ASA software versions:9.1(7.12)9.2(4.18)9.4(3.12)9.4(3.99)9.5(3.2)9.6(2.4)9.7(0.99)Note: Prior to an upgrade of the ASA software, create a backup of the system configuration with the more system:running-config command and save the output to a file. Follow the software upgrade, enter the more system:running-config command again and compare to the previous saved file in order to ensure the original configuration was restored.The software for the ASA 5500-X Series Firewalls can be downloaded from the Cisco Software Download Center.
data.caveat: Automation is not checking Software Version.  Manual verification will be required.

data.bulletinTitle: FN64228 - ASA 5506, ASA 5506W, ASA 5506H, ASA 5508, and ASA 5516 Might Fail After 18 Months or Longer Due to Clock Signal Component Failure - Replace on Failure
data.problemDescription: The Adaptive Security Appliance (ASA) 5506, ASA 5506W, ASA 5506H, ASA 5508, and ASA 5516 might fail after 18 months or longer in operation due to a clock signal component failure.
data.background: A clock signal component manufactured by one supplier, and included in some Cisco products, has been seen to degrade over time in some units.Although the Cisco products with these components are currently performing normally, we expect product failures to increase over the years, beginning after the unit has been in operation for approximately 18 months.Once the component has failed, the system will stop functioning, will not boot, and is not recoverable.To support our customers and partners, Cisco will replace products that have this component for those customers with products under warranty or covered by any valid service contract dated as of November 16, 2016.These clock signal components are used by other companies and are included in a number of Cisco products.Customers can learn more about this topic at http://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/web/clock-signal.html.
data.problemSymptoms: The security appliances no longer function and, subsequently, the system fails to boot.In addition, the LED status indicators on the security appliance illuminate as follows:- Power LED is green- Status LED is amber and blinking
data.workaround: Customers with affected products (see the How To Identify Hardware Levels section) that are under warranty or covered by any valid service contract as of November 16, 2016 should go to the Clock Signal Component Issue page and follow the instructions in order to request replacements.Due to the age-based nature of the failure and the volume of replacements, Cisco will prioritize orders based on the product's time in operation. Customers are reminded to return equipment promptly after replacement.The license activation key is tied to the ASA chassis serial number. Contact the Cisco Licensing Team in order to have your current license transferred to the replacement chassis serial number. The Cisco Licensing Team will ask for the Product Authorization Key reference number and current serial number. Additional information in regards to ASA licensing can be referenced in the Cisco ASA Series General Operations CLI Configuration Guide, 9.6.Note: There is no workaround for this issue.If you require further assistance, or if you have any further questions in regards to the information that is provided in this field notice, send an email to component-questions@cisco.com.

data.bulletinTitle: FN64233 - Nexus 3000 Series Switches That Run Release 6.0.(2)U6(x) Fail to Upgrade to Release 7.0.(x) with MD5 Sum Mismatch Error - BIOS/Firmware Upgrade Recommended
data.problemDescription: Nexus 3000 Series platforms that run Release 6.0(2)U6(x) show an MD5 mismatch when you upgrade to Release 7.0x or later (impacted software images are listed in the Background section). As a result, the switch will be in a boot loop.
data.background: Some Nexus 3000 Series platforms listed in the Products Affected section that use 2G and 4G eUSB flash are greater than 48 sector/track disk geometry. The impacted images do not understand greater than 48 sector/disk geometry and thus an upgrade to any of these images throws an MD5 mismatch error. Impacted Software Image List- 7.0(3)I5(1)- 7.0(3)I4(4)- 7.0(3)I4(3)- 7.0(3)I4(2)- 7.0(3)I4(1)- 7.0(3)I3(1)- 7.0(3)I2(4)- 7.0(3)I2(3)- 7.0(3)I2(2e)- 7.0(3)I2(2d)- 7.0(3)I2(2c)- 7.0(3)I2(2b)- 7.0(3)I2(2a)This issue will be fixed in Release 7.0(3)I2(5), 7.0(3)I4(5), 7.0(3)I5(2), and any 7.0(x) image released after December 2016. Follow the standard upgrade/downgrade guideline for the new 7.0(x) release.
data.problemSymptoms: The error message that is displayed is: Booting kickstart image: bootflash:/nxos.7.0.3.I2.4.binMD5Sum mismatch graphics_set_kernel_params enter:
data.workaround: Customers need to upgrade the BIOS before an upgrade to Release 7.0(x). See the How to Upgrade Software section for instructions.How to Upgrade SoftwareBIOS images with fixes: nxos-n3kbios.binNote: All BIOS images are available for download in the system software standard download locations. Upgrade Impacted Switches From Release 6.0(2)U6(x)An intermediate upgrade of the BIOS is needed before an upgrade to the impacted releases listed in the Background section.1. Copy the BIOS image nxos-n3kbios.bin to bootflash.2. Enter the install all nxos bootflash:nxos-n3kbios.bin bios command. This command needs to be run from Release 6.0(2)U6 and later and it upgrades only the BIOS image. It does not reload the switch.3. Once the BIOS has been upgraded, delete the BIOS image nxos-n3kbios.bin from bootflash and upgrade the switch to the previously listed impacted releases as per the normal procedure. Recover Impacted Switches if an Upgrade was Already Attempted and the Switch is in the Loader Prompt Recover the switch by downgrading to Release 6.0(2)U6(x) via booting images with TFTP from the loader prompt and then upgrade to Release 7.0.x:1. Downgrade the switch to Release 6.0(2)U6(x) from the loader prompt with TFTP and recover the box.Enter these commands from the loader prompt:break into loader prompt by Ctrl-L if the switch is in boot cycleloader>set ip ipaddress netmask loader>set gw gateway_ipaddress loader>boot tftp://tftp_server_ip/nxos.7.0.3.Ix.y.bin(boot 7.0.x release via tftp boot from loader)N3K# write eraseN3K# write erase bootN3K# copy 6.0.2.U6.x_running_config startup-configN3K# install all kickstart bootflash:n3000-uk9-kickstart.6.0.2.U6.x.bin system bootflash:n3000-uk9.6.0.2.U6.x.bin no-save bios-force (downgrade to 6.0(2)U6(x)) 2. Enter these commands in order to upgrade the switch from Release 6.0(2)U6(x) to Release 7.0.x:Copy nxos-n3kbios.bin into the switch.install all nxos nxos-n3kbios.bin biosdelete nxos-n3kbios.bininstall all nxos nxos.7.0.3.Ix.xx.bin ( upgrade to 7.0.3 based release of your choice)
data.caveat: Manual verification of Product ID is required.

data.bulletinTitle: FN64241 - cBR-8-Potential Protect Line Card Reload Due to Memory Leak - Software Upgrade Recommended
data.problemDescription: There is the potential for a cBR-8 protect line card reload due to a cdman (Cable Device Manager) memory leak.
data.background: A cable modem intermittent connectivity issue (flapping) might lead to a cdman memory leak on the cBR-8 protect line card. This issue is specific to cBR-8 Cisco IOS XE Software Release 3.18.0S while there is a line card redundancy in place.
data.problemSymptoms:
These repeated alarms are observed in the logs triggered by the cBR-8 protect line card:

> Jul  3 23:30:03.775 EDT: %IOSXE-3-PLATFORM: CLC0: cdman:   CDMINFRA CDM_PT_MEMORY_TEST SANITY TEST FAILED  
> Jul  3 23:31:03.775 EDT: %IOSXE-3-PLATFORM: CLC0: cdman:   CDMINFRA CDM_PT_MEMORY_TEST SANITY TEST FAILED  
> Jul  3 23:32:03.775 EDT: %IOSXE-3-PLATFORM: CLC0: cdman:   CDMINFRA CDM_PT_MEMORY_TEST SANITY TEST FAILED
data.workaround:
Cisco recommends that customers upgrade to Cisco IOS XE 3.18.0SP or a later release which contains the fix. Refer to this table for more information:
cBR-8 Cisco IOS XE ReleaseDoes Issue Exist?Action
3.15.0SNoNone
3.16.0SNoNone
3.16.1SNoNone
3.17.0SNoNone
3.18.0SYes Upgrade to 3.18.0SP or later release
3.18.0SP or later releaseNoNone
In order to avoid this issue in the interim, Cisco suggests to reload the protect line card if the alarm mentioned in the Problem Symptoms section is observed in the logs.
data.caveat: Manual verification of specific linecard is required.
